tours.tourDesc: Berlin's medieval heart, its better in the dark
tourBrief: Welcome to where it all began, the core of Berlin! Nikolaiviertel's medieval history contains many myths and legends... devoted priests, murdered mistresses and headless knights all want their stories told.

Go by nightfall to get the mood for a tour that leads you into Berlin's medieval heart. You'll discover Berlin's historical centre and its curious anecdotes. And its not only ghouls that come out at night, the Nikolaiviertel offers a vibrant nightlife with countless pubs and restaurants. Go and taste the ultimate Berlin experience!

stopInfo.title: Nikolaiviertel
teaser: This is where it all began! The Nikolaiviertel is the oldest settlement in Berlin and has an interesting medieval history as well as some bloodcurdling anecdotes. Today the area offers the flair of a historic district with wonderful old houses, restaurants and coffee shops bang in the middle of the city centre.
history: Together with the settlement Cölln, not to be mistaken for the city of Cologne, Berlin was founded as a twin city.
Map of Berlin and Cölln
Map of Berlin and Cölln
Exact dates and details of that time are missing due to a massive fire destroying all the documents in 1380.
The convenient location close to the river Spree brought prosperity and growth within a short time.

The Nikolaiviertel tells a fascinating tale of destruction and restoration. The bombs of Wold War II, the plague and countless fires have challenged the narrow streets of the merchant settlement and their residents.
Nikolaiviertel, 1945
Destroyed center: Destruction of Nikolaiviertel, 1945. Notice the Palace back left and Berliner Dom back right

After Wold War II the Nikolaiviertel was forgotten for a long time and its streets and building lay in ruins. It was only the 750 year celebrations of Berlin that the look of the area changed improved. Suddenly, it became important and lots of money was pumped into restoring the quarter to its former glory.

Today the Nikolaiviertel is about 50.000 square metres big with 2.000 residents living in roughly 800 apartments. 33 shops, 22 restaurants and countless little museums are looking forward to your visit.
qi: GDR officials decided to go big for the 750-year-celebrations of Berlin. The restoration of the Nikolaiviertel cost several millions and took place at the end of the 80's.
The whole project was declared a matter of the state and soon after became a vanity project for the leaders of the German Democratic Republic.
Berliners still today call the Nikolaiviertel the “Erich Honecker's Disneyland”, the head of state at the time.
look_out: Keep you eyes open, you'll find a fascinating mix of old and new. Historical façades as well as new build blocks in the typical GDR style influenced the look of the Nikolaiviertel in equal parts. Rebuilding after World War II made so called gap constructions necessary.
The gray façade of the newly built houses seem especially strange if elaborately decorated with convoluted gables, ornaments and reliefs.

stopInfo.title: The Eiergasse
teaser: The Eiergasse. A very short street with a very long history. As soon as you enter, you've probably already through it!
history: Eiergasse, 1986
With only 16 meters in length the Eiergasse is the smallest street in Berlin.
However there is still room for two houses, a fountain and lots of history.
Many Berlin maps don’t even show the Eiergasse.
Eier translates to eggs in German. Egg Alley is one on the oldest streets in Berlin, dating back to the 1200's and was originally the location of the egg market.
qi: Eiergasse used to be 50m long but bombing during the second world war completely destroyed Nikolaiviertel, including the gasse
Eiergasse, 1880
After 1945 the street completely vanished from the city plan until the area was completely renovated in 1984 in preparation for the 750 year anniversary of Berlin
Berlin other renovations meant Eiergasse had to be shortened to its current length of 16 meters
look_out: Decorative drain cover
Its easy to miss some interesting things when walking around. Check the map tour map for the location of this peculiar drain cover
next_stop: If you turn on your heel and face the road traffic you will see the next stop on our tour.
extra: Zum Paddenwirt

On the left side of the street you'll find “Zum Paddenwirt”. Its origin lays in old 1800's legend telling the story of a lazy innkeeper that one night couldn’t be arsed to get his beer barrels from his boat on the river Spree.
A leak in one of the barrels attracting hundreds of frogs. In the 19th Century, Frogs were known as Padden -> Paddenwirt -> Frog Innkeeper

The “Paddenwirt” is a real restaurant. However it originally had a different location. Asked about the history of the place the residents of the Nikolaiviertel will tell you, in the typical Berliner way, with a wink of an eye: “This all used to be grassland”.

stopInfo.title: Molkenmarkt
teaser: Berlin's oldest market square has an exciting history and legends even of its very own ghost beneath its cobblestones.
history: Molkenmarkt is the oldest market square in Berlin and used to be called “Old Market”. Don’t bother crossing the road as you can see the important bits from where you stand in the Eiergasse.
Molkenmarkt, 1785
The area was populated way before the founding of Berlin (1244) and Cölln (1237).
Prince-elector Frederick III. had the market closed and turned into a parade square.
Molkenmarkt and Altes Stadthaus
Today the Molkenmarkt functions as a highly frequented junction and the east-west-connection between Alexanderplatz and Potsdamer Platz.
Molkenmarkt (“dairy market”), 1902
In the early days the Molkenmarkt was densely populated with many residential houses but after World War II the area was razed to the ground.
Molkenmarkt „car park“
Nowadays, during rush hour, it operates in what can only be described as a car park.
next_stop: Just a couple of steps take you through the Eiergasse. After a nice walk along the back of the Nikolai Church you turn left towards the restaurant “Zum Nussbaum”. Can you hear the ghosts already?
extra: Legend has it that under the streets of the Molkenmarkt a system of underground passageways used to allow the noblemen a discreet escape from the City Palace.
It was alleged the Prince-electors of their time would secretly leave their wives to meet with their mistresses.

A young milkmaid was caught in the crossfire and stabbed by a jealous wife of a member of the House of Hohenzollern. Her lifeless body was left in the tunnels for the husband to find on his way to the secret rendezvous.
Fearing a scandal, he dumped the body in the nearby river Spree. Her ghost never found peace and roams the tunnels under the Molkenmarkt today.

stopInfo.title: „Zum Nußbaum“
teaser: The tavern „Zum Nußbaum“ is one of the oldest restaurants in Berlin. But nothing is what it seems here!
history: The restaurant was built in 1507 in the style of the late Middle Ages.
Nußbaum at Fischerinsel, 1903
But here is the kicker: The building was originally situated about 700 meters southeast of where it stands now on the southern tip of what today is the Fisher Island.
Allied air raids completely destroyed the historic building in the Fischerstraße 21 in 1943. 42 years later architect Günter Stahn recreated the original following blueprints from the 30’s.
qi: The brick built copy promises a lot of history although it can’t always deliver.
Nußbaum today

The nut tree in front of the restaurant looks quite pathetic considering it is supposed to be a couple of hundred years old. The original was replaced with the American Black Walnut Tree in the beer garden at the end of the 80’s and is what can only be described as a historic bluff.
look_out: Zum Nußbaum plaque
There is a plaque on the front of the „Zum Nußbaum“, telling the thrilling story of the Berlin tavern.
next_stop: Leave the “Nußbaum” to your right and walk towards the main entrance of the Nikolai Church. The ghost of a dedicated priest awaits you there! Buh!
extra: Bar fights surely weren’t invented in modern times. In the 16th century many reports suggest alcoholic differences. The residents of Berlin and Cölln would oftentimes engage in bar fights. Legend has it that you can still hear their angry screams after midnight. If those are really ghosts or merely the noises of modern Berlin’s nightlife is up to you to decide.

attractions.busStop: The Death of a Devoted Priest

stopInfo.title: Nikolai Church
teaser: A fascinating construction that goes hand in hand with the early history of Berlin and a noble priest that even after death looks out for his congregation.
history: The Nikolai Church is the oldest church in Berlin.
The name goes back to Nikolaos the Wonder worker who was mainly worshiped by traders showing that the church was originally built in a merchant’s settlement.
Nikolai Church, right, 1250
Construction started in 1230 and saw a 40 meter long, cross-shaped basilica made of fieldstone and consisting of three naves being built.
A clever trick for free labour: In 1460 bishop Dietrich IV. declared that everybody who was to help restoring the church within a year would gain 40 days of indulgence.
In 1470 the building had developed into a late Gothic hall church.
Prior to the towers, 1852
In the years from 1876 until 1878 the two towers were added to complement the overall architectural impression.
Ruined interior
In 1944 however the towers, the roof and most of the vault of the Nikolai Church were bombed heavily.
War ravaged, 1951
Towards the very end of the war a fire ravaged the building so devastatingly that only the outside walls of the church left standing.
Prior to reconstruction, 1982
Nikolaikirche reconstruction, 1987

Within the scope of the Berlin 750-year-celebrations the reconstruction of the Nikolai Church started. The place of worship was rebuilt in the years from 1980 until 1983 following original blueprints and old drawings.

During the same time, archaeological digs found traces of an old graveyard with around 150 tombs. The findings were dated back to the end of the 12th and the beginning of the 13th century showing that Berlin was populated more than 50 years earlier than assumed.
Since 1987 the church functions as a museum with exhibitions, lectures and concerts.
Every Friday you can enjoy a concert, the so called “Nikolai-Music”.
qi: Children under 18 years of age don’t have to pay entrance. Every first Wednesday of the month the entrance is free!
look_out: In front of the entrance of the Nikolai Church a memorial plate representing the Berlin town seal reminds visitors of the fact, Johann I. and Otto III. bestowed the city rights to the settlement in 1230.
Stadtsiegel, Gerhard Thieme
Artist Gerhard Thieme designed the plate, which has a diameter of 2,20 meters, in 1987.
Founding Fountain, Gerhard Thieme
Next to the entrance of the building you can have a look at the beautiful Founding Fountain, also called the Crest Fountain.
It too was designed by Gerhard Thieme in 1987 and is made of sandstone and steel.
Walking up three stairs you will reach the octagonal four meter wide basin of the fountain.
In its middle a six meter tall column with a bear on top towers over the fountain. The composition is housed by dome railings made of iron.
next_stop: Standing in front of the main entrance of the church you turn around and walk straight for a little bit. Reaching the next crossroad you turn right. There you will find the old courthouse of Berlin – A place that makes some horror movies look like a children’s birthday party – there will be blood!
extra: In the year 1576 the Black Death fell upon Berlin and Cölln yet again. It was the fifth time already since the beginning of the century that the plague ravaged the narrow alleyways of the settlement.
The priests of many churches during those trying times had not only just the duty of spiritual guidance but also as doctors, pharmacists and grave diggers.
The devoted priest of the Nikolai Church paid the ultimate price by dying of the pestilence. Legend has it, that his ghost still roams the halls, watching over his flock.

stopInfo.title: The Gerichtslaube
teaser: The axe swung quite literally in the old courthouse. The medieval punishments of the past make every horror movie look like a big fluffy ball of cosiness. It comes as no surprise that this old court house is swarming with ghosts.
history: The Gerichtslaube, or courthouse, was built in 1270 and has been refurbished regularly since then. The existence of a court house was paramount for the independent status as a city.
Gerichtslaube Pillory

The building gained an almost cultish character in the Middle Ages. Punishments were extremely severe and cruel and was the best entertainment around-b2-Even the smallest misdemeanors were punished heavily by cutting ears, crushing teeth and blinding by hot irons.-b2-Thieves were chained to the pillory and yelled, spat and kicked at by the mob.-b2-Stealing a single fish, as old documents show, had the culprit buried alive.-b2-Small mercies for children: Convicted for stealing they met “a swift death”.-b2-In 1482, a convict died from injuries sustained by a beating because his jailers forgot to unchain him from the pillory.
Gerichtslaube Interior
Today you will find a cosy restaurant with a beautiful cellar-vault on location.
On the exact same spot where tourist nowadays enjoy a nice cold drink in the beer garden, convicts used to beg for their lives and hoped to be spared from cruel punishment. Cheers!
look_out: One of the windows facing the beer garden has the armoured helmet of Erich von Falke on its window sill. His cruel fate is explained below.
next_stop: Leave the Gerichtslaube to your right and walk straight ahead to the main road. Reaching the corner, channel your attention to your left. Here you will see the Berlin City Castle. It is haunted by an especially cruel and deadly ghost. Read everything about the Woman in White on your way towards the castle. Make sure not to trip or run into a street light.
extra: In August of the year 1380 a huge fire ravaged the streets of the Nikolaiviertel killing hundreds of residents. The mob screamed out for a scapegoat. He was found soon in form of a knight called Erich von Falke. His arbitrary handling of toll money had made him many enemies over the years.

The city council had Erich followed and killed. But the citizens of Berlin weren’t satisfied yet and the Gerichtslaube became the stage of a mock trial in which the corpse of the knight was sentenced to death.
His remains were beheaded and paraded in public.
This desecration of his corpse made it impossible for Erich to find peace. His ghost roams the halls of the Gerichtslaube still.

stopInfo.title: Berlin City Castle
teaser: Even if the White Woman does not roam the halls of the City Castle right now, the building has a fascinating past and a chaotic future.
history: The former private residence became the Berlin City Castle in the 19th century.
Stadtschloss, 1900
The building used to be an imposing structure in what today is called the historic middle of Berlin.
Stadtschloss, 1685
In 1442 prince-elector Frederick II. had the idea for the castle. Back then the twin city Berlin-Cölln was still rather insignificant.
Stadtschloss, 1847
At the beginning of the 18th century, the Prussian kings started using the castle as their home address and in 1871 the building became an imperial residence.
Stadtschloss with Swasticas, 1936
During times of the Weimar Republic the building was used as a museum hosting countless art exhibitions and concerts.
Devastated Palace & Dom, 1945

Heavy air attacks during the night of February 3rd 1945 caused the City Castle to burn out. All that was left were the façades and the northwest wing. At the end of April heavy artillery damages the façade further more due to the Battle for Berlin.
Stadtschloss destruction, 1950
The City Castle faced its final demise on September 7th 1950. Following the order of East German politician Walter Ulbricht the building was blown up in front of the eyes of hundreds of protesters.
The building made room for the so called Marx-Engels-Platz and was sporadically used for open air events.
Politician Erich Honecker ordered the construction of the so called “Palace of the Republic” in 1971.

The venue had the unflattering nickname “Honecker’s Lampshade Store” and was built with tons of asbestos. After the reunification of Germany the Palace had to close its doors due to security and health concerns.
In 2003 the demolition of the building was agreed upon and five years later the area yet again was completely empty.
Stadtschloss latest rebuild, 2015

On June 12th 2013 the first stone of what should one day become the new Berlin City Castle was laid. This rebuilt is one of the most discussed projects in all of Berlin. Three of the old baroque façades will be reconstructed.
The official opening is planned for September 14th 2019. Knowing Berlin’s luck with chaotic building sites á la BER airport most Berliners won’t hold their breath for that date to stand though.
qi: Oops! During photography for a soviet movie called “The Battle for Berlin” in October 1949 soldiers accidentally destroyed a fair amount of sculptures, exhibits and hundreds of glass windows in the Castle.
look_out: In front of the main entrance to the Berlin City Castle you will find the Humboldt Box.

Spread over three floors, there is countless information on the building progress and the tricky details for the reconstruction for whoever is interested. Under the new name of Humboldt Forum, the former castle aims to be a centre for art, culture and science.
The Box also has a terrace which, thanks to a lift can also be accessed by wheelchair users, you can enjoy the beautiful panorama of the Lustgarten, the Museum Island and the Dom.
The entrance is free!
next_stop: From the bridge we take you back into the Nikolaiviertel. Enjoy a calming walk along the river. On the opposite bank you'll see another impressive façade. This was the emperor's stables. Needless to say that the so called Marstall has its very own ghost haunting the former hutch.
extra: This unknown ghoul has spread fear and terror for many centuries in the Berlin City Palace. Even field commander Napoleon never wanted to meet her! Her wrath has been felt as recently as National Socialism times, bringing death to people who anger her.
Let try and trace the origin of the Lady in White. Who was the ghost most Berliners has heard of?

Legend has it that the ghost always appears in a white gown with a white widow‘s veil. If she is wearing black gloves, it means bad news and most likely will be followed by a death in the Hohenzollern family.

There are three possible suspects to whom the she was. The ghost was first seen before the death of Prince-elector Johann Georg in 1598. Many years before, he had promised his father, prince-elector Joachim II. on his death bed to watch over his mistress Anna Sydow. Not only did Johann Georg break that promise, he also had his father‘s concubine arrested. Anna died a horrible death in the Spandau Fortress just outside of Berlin.

Other sources suggest the ghost belongs to a countess called Agnes, the wife of count Otto who both lived in the 13th or 14th century. After her husband‘s death, Agnes lived alone with her two children until she met a guy called Albrecht the Beautiful. The countess fell head over heels for the young nobleman. But he allegedly said: „I would love to marry you if is wasn‘t for those four eyes“. Assuming that Albrecht meant her children, the countess had the boy and the girl killed. Other authors suggest she even murdered them herself, getting them out of the way of her „one and only true love“. Unfortunately, Albrecht meant his own parents when he talked about „those four eyes“. He ended up marrying another woman and Agnes was left behind to pay for her sins for all eternity.

Our third possibility is that the Woman in White is some kind of personified a bad conscience. Allegedly, the ghost is a woman by the name of Berta von Hohenzollern. She was married to Johann von Lichtenstein and had a tough job looking after him because Johann liked drinking and whoring like no other.  His lifestyle ultimately brought him to an early grave and on his dead bed he realized he should have listened to his wife. Berta‘s ghost appears to other members of her family as a warning.

Prince-elector Johann Sigismund, the grandson of Johann Georg, was so scared of the Woman in White that he sought refuge in the nearby Nikolaiviertel. The yearly „Festival of Lights“ sees the two towers of the Nikolai Church bathed in white light as an homage to that story. All for nothing though: Johann Sigismund died in 1619 shortly after seeing a vision of the Woman in White. And yes, you guessed right – The lady was wearing black gloves!
When the Woman in White doesn‘t wear her black gloves she is supposed to be rather peaceful, looking after the Palace and its residents. If, however, you provoke her, you’re in for a 'bit of bother'.

From the History of the Berlin Palace, Eberhard Cyran writes: „In the month of May of the 2nd year of war, the White Woman showed herself… One of Himmlers officers volunteered to stand guard and chase after the ghost. In the night from Saturday to Sunday, the 26th of May (shortly before the war with France started), a shot lit up the whole Berlin City Palace with such force that the eyes of the people standing outside started to hurt. The next morning the officer was found with a broken neck and his pistol with the safety catch off...“
The fate of the Woman in White is very much bound to the Palace. On January 31st 1945, three days before the Castle was bombed to the grounds, the Lady showed herself for the last time.

That is until now of course. For the last few years, the Berlin City Palace has been under reconstruction... following the original blueprints. We shall see whether the Woman in White will take up residence again when the Palace reopens. Or maybe she has never left the grounds and is standing right behind you!

stopInfo.title: The Neuer Marstall
teaser: Hundreds of horses romping over four floors! An underground tunnel and the sad fate of a young couple leave people baffled until today.
history: Let’s first of all explain the name of the building. “Marah” means horse in Old High German. “Stall” today still is the German word for stable. Therefore the Neuer Marstall means something along the lines of New Stables. The building was mainly used by rich nobleman. A demographic group Berlin had plenty of back in the early days of the city.
Neuer Marstall, 1906
The Neuer Marstall on Spree Island was built in a neo-baroque style following the designs of architect Ernst Eberhard von Ihne from 1897 until 1901.
As “The King’s Stables” the four storey building was used to house more than 300 horses, countless stately carriages and winter proof sledges.
During World War II the Marstall was bombed heavily. The Battle for Berlin left the façade with countless bullet holes which were merely repaired in 1952.
Neuer Marstall, north view
Today the Marstall is home to the “Hanns Eisler” Academy for Music, parts of Berlin’s state library and offices of the Association for Berlin History.
qi: The Berlin City Castle and the Neue Marstall are connected by an underground tunnel. During the times of the prince-electors the corridor used to be rather small.
However when the City Castle was torn down and replaced by the Palace of the Republic the tunnel was widened to two meters in height and width.

The German “Bild-Zeitung” (a bit like the British Sun or American National Enquirer) reported in 2016 that the tunnel was used by leader of the German Democratic Republic Erich Honecker as a potential escape route in case the people of the GDR would ever turn against him. All sensationalism aside, the tunnel was never used to bring the politician to safety but rather for simple means of transport.
look_out: At the main entrance of the Marstall there are two bronze reliefs made by artist Gerhard Rommel.
Neuer Marstall, 1906
Neuer Marstall, 1906
They were erected in 1988 commemorating the 70th anniversary of the German Revolution of 1918–19 and replaced two fountains that used to be installed on both sides of the entrance.
Poseidon taming the horses, Otto Lessing
The façade facing the river Spree hints at the original use of the Marstall showing “taming the horses.” group by sculptor Otto Lessing.
next_stop: Keep walking alongside of the river Spree and you will reach a six meter high statue of “Saint George and the Dragon”. A thrilling story of a noble virgin, a brave knight and an evil dragon awaits you there.
extra: Once a young stable boy worked in the Marstall. He fell in love with a beautiful peasant girl working as a maidservant. Unfortunately her beauty attracted the attention of a nobleman living in the City Castle. Instead of leading a miserable existence as the mistress of a violent drunk, the young girl ended her life.

When the stable boy learned of the fate of his beloved, he threw himself into the river Spree. Legend has it that until today the two lovers are still searching for each other, haunting the walls of the Neuer Marstall.

attractions.busStop: What the hell is he doing here?

stopInfo.title: Saint George
teaser: A brave knight, a helpless princess, a cruel dragon and a fight that ultimately shaped an empire. Read the story of Saint George and the Beast!
history: The group plastic was made in 1855 by artist August Kiß.

In 1865 “Saint George” was exhibited at the Berlin City Castle. After its demolition the statue found a new home in the Volkspark Friedrichshain, a beautiful public park in the Berlin borough of Friedrichshain.
St George in Nikolaiviertel
In 1987 “Saint George” was brought to the Nikolaiviertel where he towers over the historic houses ever since.
qi: Saint George is no commissioned piece. Artist August Kiß was quite well off and built the plastic out of his own pocket finally donating it to the state of Prussia.
look_out: Have a closer look at the plastic to appreciate the skills of August Kiß.
St George in detail

The horse of Saint George rears up over the dragon laying helpless on the floor. The brave knight himself acts calm, focused and prudent. His behaviour symbolises the overcoming of savagery and passion. This act of self-control is vital to defeat evil. The dragon of course stands for everything that is bad in the world.
next_stop: Keep going straight along the river Spree. On the next corner you turn to the left and keep walking until you reach the The Ephraim-Palais and its beautiful golden balconies.
extra: In the Libyan city of Silena once a cruel dragon lived near the settlement in a lake. Whenever the beast felt like it came to the city walls and demanded gold, food or a human sacrifice.
Were his wishes ignored the dragon would seriously damage the city with “his poisonous breath”.
Every day the residents of Silena drew lots for who was to be the next sacrifice. One day the fate fell on the only daughter of the king.
He had no choice but to bring her to the lake. There the young princess met Saint George and told him about her tragic destiny. But the knight said: “Worry not, child! I will help you.
George used his lance to kill the dragon swiftly.
Back home the princess told everyone about her miraculous rescue. Saint George left such a huge impression with his bravery that a majority of the people living in Silena would go and get baptised.
Exactly: Saint George didn’t just marry the princes, as custom in so many other legends and fairy tales. He conversed a whole empire to Christianity probably securing himself a kingdom in heaven.

stopInfo.title: The Ephraim-Palais
teaser: You are standing on “Berlin’s most beautiful corner”. But even here nothing is what it seems at first. One resident of the mansion found a particular gruesome end.
history: In 1766, an extremely wealthy banker by the name of Veitel Heine Ephraim had the palais built following the designs of master builder Friedrich Wilhelm Diterichs. Unfortunately, this meant Berlin’s oldest pharmacy had to be relocated
As the court jeweler and leaseholder of the mint under Frederick William II, King of Prussia, Ephraim was very influential and rich.
In 1936 the Palais was demolished due to growing traffic causing the need for bigger streets and a bridge in the area.
The façade and other architectural components were stored in Wedding (a borough of Berlin) where they survived Wold War II without a scratch.
In 1985 the house rose like phoenix from the ashes twelve meters from where it used to stand and used most of the original structures.
Today the State Museum Berlin offers interesting exhibitions concerning the history of Berlin and the Graphic Collection.
look_out: Every first Wednesday of the month the entrance to the Ephraim-Palais is free!
Ephraim-Palais cherubs
Both wings of the building are connected by a rounded corner. The main entrance is framed by a number of cherubs (the happy chubby kids on the first floor) and Tuscan columns.
next_stop: Follow the main road Mühlendamm straight on. On your left side you will pass a little public green space. Arriving at the next house, you should look up. There is a massive rib hanging from the façade. What “female trickery” killed the last of the giants in the area? You will find out at our next stop.
extra: Veitel Heine Ephraim had to endure envy and malevolence coming from his status and wealth. This however was nothing compared to the fate of Lippold Ben Chluchim. The old mint was located just around the corner (Poststraße 4) from 1540 until 1585. Its Mint Master had a difficult job.
Lippold walked a thin red line. The last Jew Pogrom had only ended some 30 years ago but prince-elector Joachim II. Hektor was in dire need of money and allowed the Jews back into the city.
It was Lippold’s job to get the “protection money” from his peers.
When the prince-elector unexpectedly died in 1571 of a tracheal cough Lippold was accused of witchcraft and poisoning by the prince-electors son Johann Georg.

Under gruesome torture the former Mint Master admitted the possession of a Book of Spells and was soon after executed. Legend has it that you can hear his desperate screams after nightfall until today.

attractions.busStop: Giants used to live in Berlin!

stopInfo.title: Restaurant „Zur Rippe“
teaser: Giant Robert was actually just looking for love. What he found instead was a cruel death. How exactly he was murdered, you will read here.
history: There isn’t much known about the actual history of the building. The house today is home to a restaurant entertaining its customers with not one but two legends about giants in Berlin.
So what’s the story behind the massive bones on the façade?
look_out: Giant's rib
Over the entrance to the restaurant you can see a giant rib and the bones of a shoulder blade nailed to the façade that point to giants once roaming the area.
next_stop: Standing on front of the restaurant entrance you best keep walking straight, pass the little green area. Follow the Poststraße and stop in front of the number 23. The Knoblauch House goes way back in history. Are you interested in finding out what role the building played in awarding the Iron Cross? Then you should read all about it on our next stop.
extra: Both legends are assuming that the area around Berlin used to be inhabited by giants.
Two of them allegedly terrorised the market square quite regularly. A young maid one day had it with the crude hulks and threw a wagon load of eggs in front of them.

The giants slipped on the yolk and once on the ground one of them was beaten to death by an angry mob. His shoulder blade and one of his ribs was nailed to the façade of the restaurant “Zur Rippe” (“Rippe” means rib in German) as a warning to other giants to stay away.

Another legend tells the tale of a giant called Robert. He was the only one left of his kind in the region. Robert felt lonely and started looking for a female companion. Because he could not find any other giants, he said to himself: “Size doesn’t matter!”
So Robert abducted a young Berliner woman. Her fiancé, a strong blacksmith, understandably wasn’t too thrilled and swore vengeance.

The young woman didn't lose hope and feigned feelings for Robert. With his guard down and fast asleep, her the young maiden called for her fiancé and a couple of his friends. They swiftly killed Robert in his sleep.

The legend of Robert was first published in a book called „Sagen und Miscellen aus Berlins Vorzeit“ in the year 1831. Not a single giant has ever been seen in Nikolaiviertel... so Robert may really have been the last one.

attractions.busStop: A family business with a very long tradition.

stopInfo.title: Knoblauch House
teaser: A family business with a long history and a night watchman with an eternal bad consciousness. You are standing in front of a building with an exciting tradition. Learn more about the business idea that is recognized all over the world.
history: The Knoblauch House is one of the few residences of the 18th century that today can still be found on its original location.
From 1759 until 1761 a very rich Tayler named Johann Christian Knoblauch had the house built after tearing down an old building on the plot.
In 1806 the Knoblauch House was renovated and the baroque façade replaced by a classicistic style. 29 years later the artful cornice gave the building its final touch.
The building survived the air attacks of World War II without considerable damage which was nothing short of a small miracle back in the days.
Since 1989 the Knoblauch House is used as a museum. Visitors can get an impression of the cultivation of home décor in the Biedermeier period (1815 to 1848).
qi: Patriarch Johann Christian Knoblauch lived and worked in the Knoblauch House. He manufactured knitting needles, sifters and grilles. His main employee was the military though. Knoblauch made hooks, metal loops and chains for the uniforms of soldiers.
His sons later focussed on the production of silk ribbons.
Iron Cross Class II, 1813
In 1813 the family Knoblauch started to manufacture the ribbons to which the Iron Cross was attached.
look_out: The ground floor of the Knoblauch House is very uneven and trapeze shaped. Three of the four façades are detached, slightly curved and have a circulating cornice on top of the windows in the second story.
The first floor is decorated with a flower oriel.
next_stop: Walk around the Knoblauch House into a street called „Nikolaikirchplatz“. Along the way you can enjoy a view of the nave aisle of the Nikolai Church. On the right site you will get back to the Eiergasse (where we started our tour). Walk once again through the Eiergasse. It shouldn’t take long. Turn left into the main road. At the traffic lights you cross the road. Walk the road „Molkenmarkt“ for about 260 meters. There you turn left into the „Klosterstraße“. On the right side of the road you will find the so called Parochialkirche, a parish church. Not long ago scientists found headless mummies in its crypt.
extra: In 1380 a massive fire ravaged the streets of the Nikolaiviertel killing countless residents.
Legend has it that a majority of the people living in the area could have been saved if the night watchman had only done his job.
Medieval night watchmen were supposed to patrol the streets after nightfall. They would warn the citizens in case of plunder, enemies and fire.
It was an important job that without any incidences could get very boring after a while.

And so it happened that on that fateful summer night in 1380 the night watchmen turned to wine and fell asleep. He missed the outbreak of the fire and his ghost must look over the people of the Nikolaiviertel for all eternity as penance.

attractions.busStop: You just couln‘t make that stuff up!

stopInfo.title: Parish Church
teaser: Desecration of corpses, headless mummies and a religious swindle that had countless noblemen fooled. The story of the so called Parochialkirche could teach you a new meaning of fear!
history: Parochialkirche was commisioned in 1694 and was the first post-Reformation building of its kind in Berlin. Frederick III allowed the purchase of the land for the purpose of building a new church and one year later the foundation stone was laid in the presence of the elector and entire court

Head of construction was Leonhard Braun, one of the richest men of his time. Although he fancied himself a master builder, he had no concept of architecture and was dismissed from his previous projects due to incompetence or faulty construction work... he had something of the reverse midas touch

Instead of the simple, light plank dome that was planned, he had a massive dome installed that ultimately made the whole east side of the church collapse under the weight. Although he avoided imprisonment due to his vast wealth, he had pay for the damage and repairs out of his own pocket and was asked never to build again
The grand opening of the Parochialkirche was celebrated on June 8th 1703 with the King of Prussia and his wife Sophie Charlotte in attendance.
Parochialkirche crosses
It is one of the oldest graveyards in the city as shown on the graves, crosses and memorial plaques.

Documents show that starting from 1706 the first Berliners were laid to rest on the church yard. Regardless of the small space exactly 5.338 burials on the ground and 247 funerals in the vaults were accounted for.

Back in those days only rich nobleman could afford a burial here. With the whopping cost of 400 gold coins (around 40.000 Euros in today’s money) just a few people could afford eternal peace in the Parochialkirche. However the church elders were good businessmen, making the coffins disappear after a couple of years and reusing the space for new “customers”.
On May 24th 1944 countless bombs fell on the church. The tower caught fire, burnt out and crashed into the nave bay. The complete inventory burnt down and the church bells melted.
Interior and Iron Cross
Artist Fritz Kühn made an iron cross out of pieces of scrap metal he found in and around the church. It hangs on the walls of the presbytery now.
On August 20th, one week after the building of the Berlin Wall had started, the last official service was read in the Parochialkirche.
During GDR times, the building was initially used for exhibitions and concerts, and from 1970 onwards as a furniture store room.
Parochialkirche interior Innenraum
In 1988 the parish church was finally given a new roof. The interior is kept in a state of partial restoration as part of the monument-preserving concept
qi: In 1986 unknown jokers stole a mummy from the crypt to have some fun with. The body belonged to a woman who had died 300 years previous. The remains still showed distinctive red hair, which is why Berliners call the lady “Red Else” until today. At the end of the night the mummy was placed at the entrance of the metro station „Klosterstraße“

A newspaper article of the Berliner Zeitung read the next day: “Horribly shriveled she sat on the stairs […] her skin was yellow, the hair glowed red. She didn’t die yesterday, the coroner noted straight away. More like 300 years ago.”
look_out:
The most famous people here were buried during the 18th and 19th century. Look out for:
  • Theologian Daniel Ernst Jablonski, 1660–1741
  • The famous Osman soldier Friedrich Aly, ca. 1666–1716
  • The imperial nanny Auguste Henriette Bock, 1762–1845
  • The founder of the Berlin China Factory Wilhelm Caspar Wegely.
The last two people to be buried here were unnamed war dead in 1945.
next_stop: Left of the main entrance of the church you enter the „Parochialstraße“. During the day you can visit the church yard from here. At the end of the road you should have a beer in one of Berlin’s oldest pubs. The restaurant “Zur letzten Instanz” used to be located with its back against the old city wall. Many legends surround the old in.
extra: An inventory of the crypt took place at the end of 2000. Of the 110 coffins that were opened, 140 corpses were found. Seems over the centuries some “double booking” occured.
25 of the bodies had had their head ripped of the rest of their body. Further investigation showed that some of the heads didn’t match the corpse they were buried with.

Turns out a professor from the medical faculty had told his students to use the Parochialkirche as a source for dead bodies (especially their heads) to practice dissections. After their studies some of the students brought back the remains but put them in the wrong coffins, turning the mummies in the crypt into some kind of morbid puzzle.
It goes without saying that this desecration of the bodies left some souls very unhappy. Their ghosts haunt the crypt and the graveyard of the church until today.

attractions.busStop: Life on the edge of society.

stopInfo.title: Restaurant „Zur letzten Instanz“
teaser: Living on the edge of civilisation: The restaurant „Zur letzten Instanz“ used to be located with its back to the old city wall of Berlin. Countless VIPs have eaten here over the centuries. Discover how the pub got its name.
history: In 1621 the former cavalry captain of the prince-elector opened a restaurant in a building that was mentioned in an official document dating back to the year 1561.
The house was located with its back to the old city wall and was most likely built in the 13th century.
In the 20s, the restaurant became more of a hipster location with countless famous customers like Henny Porten, Charly Chaplin, Heinrich Zille, Clara Zetkin, Wilhelm Raabe and Otto Nagel.
In 1924 a courthouse was built opposite the restaurant. Since then it is called “Zur letzten Instanz” which translates to “To the last resort”.
qi: Uncomfortable!

Have a look insider the place. It’s worth it! Right at the entrance you will see a beautiful  200+ year old tiled stove. On it, French emperor Napoleon Bonaparte allegedly had a rest. I can personally say its not very comfortable
look_out: Berlin City Wall
The beer garden offers room for more than 50 guests. From here you can also see a small leftover of the historic city wall.
Berlin City Wall
The structure used to be six meter high sporting lots of turrets.
Attackers first had to overcome a trench and escape the arrows of the watchmen before even reaching the city wall.
next_stop: Follow the “Waisenstraße” to the end. From here you should see the ruins of the Franciscan Abbey (Franziskaner-Klosterkirche). A limping monk, dreadful screams of terror and a rather exceptional love story await you on our next stop.
extra: Legend has it that two farmers once had a fight spanning over many years, some say even generations. After sharing a drunken night of honesty, the two wranglers finally agreed on letting the dispute go. The case was resolved in the last resort giving the pub its German name “Zur letzten Instanz”.

attractions.busStop: Can you hear the screams of the limping monk?

stopInfo.title: Franciscan Abbey Church
teaser: The former abbey hasn’t been a functioning church for some time. Could the screams of Father Roderich, the limping monk, have something to do with that? Discover his tragic fate below
history: Building of the abbey started in 1250 making the ruin one of the most important pieces of the founding of Berlin. The abbey was originally thought to be a mendicant church for the Franciscan monks and measured 52m long and 16m wide.
The 13th century already saw the abbey being rebuilt in the three-aisled basilica style. Prince-elector Ludwig VI. of Bavaria was buried here in 1365.

When the Reformation came to Berlin in 1539 the church was closed. In 1571 a printing company moved into the brick building. Three years later the grammar school called “Gymnasium of the Grey Abbey” opened on the grounds.
Kloster Ruin, 1951
Heavy bombing in the night of April 3rd 1945 nearly destroyed the abbey completely.
Only five years later the debris was finally cleared. Starting from 1963 the building was declared save.
Latest reconstruction, 2009
Another restoration followed in the years 2003/04. Since then the former abbey makes a splendid location for exhibitions, theater plays and concerts.
qi: „Gymnasium of the Grey Abbey“ interior, 1910
The grammar school “Gymnasium of the Grey Abbey” had countless famous pupils over the centuries e.g. Karl Friedrich Schinkel, Friedrich Ludwig Jahn, Theodor Fontane and Otto von Bismarck.
look_out: Inside the ruin of the old abbey many interesting, yet ever changing, exhibitions take place. For the latest program check their homepage at the link above.
next_stop: Congratulations! You have finished quite a trip through medieval Berlin. Have a beer or a lemonade and maybe buy us one too... the donate button is just below. We really hope you enjoyed the tour. If you've any comments, let us know. That button is below too
extra: Listen carefully... terrible screams have been documented coming from the abbey since 1320 and legend has it they are the wailings of regret from Father Roderich.
As a young man, Roderich fell in love with the daughter of a castle owner. The young lady lived in a tower and, much like Rapunzel, would throw Roderich a rope to climb.

Daddy got wind of the affair and wasn’t best pleased. His guards caught Roderich in the tower and, seeing no other escape, Roderich jumped. It wasn't a good leap and resulted in a limp that would stay for the rest of his days.

This all came too late however... the daughter was already pregnant. The resulting baby boy, Bernhard, was raised as a godson, Roderich was banished and the lady married a suitor picked by her father.

She and her husband had a daughter named Luise. In the following years, Bernhard and Luise became closer than perhaps they should. Mother, being somewhat worried, sent Bernhard to this very abbey. As misfortune would have it, this is the abbey to which Roderich was banished. Roderich's bitterness had only grown in the years and his frustrations quenched only with torture and murder, his favorite pastimes.

Back home, Luise, having discovered her family ties, wrote Bernhard a letter explaining everything. Bernhard took this knowledge badly and picked a fight with Roderich. The limping monk imprisoned and practiced his hobby on the young man in the cellar of the abbey.

Sometime later Roderich, having read letter, realised that Bernhard was his son. He rushed to free the young man but he'd become too accomplished at his hobby! Roderich, overcome at having murdered his own son, confessed to all his past crimes and was beaten to death by an angry mob.
The same scream of agony and regret that was uttered when he'd murdered his son can still be heard today, howling through the ruins of the old abbey.

tours.tourDesc: Use your day ticket to see popular Berlin attractions
tourBrief: A cheap alternative to the hop on/hop off bus tour of Berlin. This tour offers a simple way to make your own sightseeing tour at the cost of a day ticket or the Berlin Welcome Card. We'll show you where the important attractions are and you decide if you want to hop off the bus for a closer look or just stay in the bus and enjoy looking at them in passing.
For the best views, use the upper deck and if you're quick, try and get the seats above the driver for panoramic views of the city's attractions.

stopInfo.title: S+U Zoologischer Garten
teaser: You are at Zoo, the train station not the animal park. Even though you might meet more interesting creatures in their crazy habitat here.
Built in 1882 it inspired a bunch of artists and has a lot of history. Some of it even interesting. Check out the details below!
history: Zoologischer Garten - 1900
The station opened on February 7th 1882, and in 1902 the underground train U2 followed. Until the reunification of Germany Bahnhof Zoo was the most significant Train station in West Germany.

During the 70s and 80s the backstreet of the train station, the Jebensstraße, was a popular meeting point for the drug and prostitution scene. The book “We Children from Bahnhof ZOO” shows the bottomless pit of that time in a very impressive way. Towards the end of the 80s police would raid the area more often hoping to make Zoo safer. In reality though the area up until a couple of years ago was still understood to be a very bad neighborhood.
Breitscheidplatz at night
Building the 5 star hotel „Waldorf Astoria“ polished up that image.
The famous shopping mile „Kurfürstendamm“ is in walking distance from the train station. If you haven't found the map yet, just click the top image or rotate your device.
qi: The Irish band U2 was inspired here to write the song “Zoo station”.

The famous photographer Helmut Newton saw the building Nr. 2 in Jebensstraße on the backside of Zoo station last before he left Berlin for Los Angeles. He had to flee the country. In 2004 the museum for photography opened exactly here following the last wish of Newton, whose pictures can be seen in a permanent exhibition on the first floor.
The Swedish punk band Randy sings about the lack of hope and bleak perspective in the song “Bahnhof Zoo“.
The famous song “Big in Japan” by Alphaville dedicated a line to the train station.
Bernd Brandes took a train in March 2001 to go from Zoo to the German city Kassel. He there would meet Armin Meiwes, the man that killed and ate him making him famous as the “Rotenburg Cannibal”.
look_out: The Lost and Found for trains, buses and S-Bahns can be found in the building. So if you forgot your umbrella on the bus this is the place to look for it.
The roof of the station is protected as a site of historic interest and was built 1998 by the plans of architects Charles de Picciotto and Jörg Steinwender.
The train station is “smoke free” since February 15th 2004 which means smoking is prohibited.
next_stop: It’s only 350m to the Breitscheidplatz.

stopInfo.title: Breitscheidplatz
teaser: You are at Breitscheidplatz now. Have a look around. Spend the day if you like. There is shed load to see here. First off of course the massive church with no proper roof. Find out that story and enjoy a drink in a bar with an interesting history. I can feel some fact to show off coming up:
history: The „Breitscheidplatz“ was promoted as some kind of equivalent to the East German “Alexanderplatz”.
Breitscheidplatz memorial

The Breitscheidplatz rose to tragic fame when terrorist Anis Amri drove a lorry into a crowd gathering at the Christmas Marked on the night of December 19th 2016. The attack left twelve people dead and 56 visitors wounded.
Romanische Café - 1908
There once was a famous „Romanische Café“ in front of what is today known as the Europa center. Famous novelists and poets of the 1920ies would meet here.
Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church
The Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church is located on the square.

The skyscraper on the square was built from 1963 until 1965 and soon after became a famous landmark of the “Breitscheidplatz”. Today the building is called the “Europacenter” and stretches over 22 floors.
During the winter month you can find a lovely Christmas market on the square.
The fountain in front of the Europacenter is called “Weltkugelbrunnen” but true Berliners refer to it as “Wasserklops” which translates to water meatball.
Weltkugelbrunnen / Wasserklops
The fountain was built in 1983 and opened to the public on August 12th. The bronze statues were created by sculptor Joachim Schmettau.
Upkeep for the fountain is expensive. Five months of maintenance cost the district of Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf about 75.000 Euros. Therefore the “Weltkugelbrunnen“ desperately depends on sponsors.
qi: Most of the constructions on the “Breitscheidplatz” were built by Italian guest-workers. Many of them stayed in Berlin after they finished the job and still live in the area.

During the last few years the government tried to restore the square to its former glory, sometimes going a little overboard. A year ago an official requirement forbid the Bars and Cafés in the area to have plastic chairs. Thankfully this regulation was dropped soon after as “nonsense”.
look_out: In the cellar of the Europa center hides a very famous Irish Pub that makes for interesting nights out. Also, there are plenty of shopping opportunities during the day.
The turning Mercedes Benz star on top of the skyscraper is lovingly referred to by Berliners as “Tittle” or “Dot over the i”.

During summer lots of street artists use the pavement as a canvas for their creations. They don’t mind if you watch them for a while and are very willing to answer any question. So don’t be shy and talk to them.

When weather allows Eddie Harck and his crew perform regularly on the square. They will blow you away with a skate and break-dance show you will tell your friends and family about. The show is for free, donations would be appreciated though.
Opposite the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church we have the new build Hotel Motel One Berlin-Upper West. Its bar offers spectacular views into the neighboring zoo and across the city.
next_stop: The memory church deserves its own entry... be sure to check it out before getting back on the bus.

stopInfo.title: Kaiser Wilhelm Memory Church
teaser: One of the most famous monuments of war and its destruction, the Kaiser Wilhelm Memory Church, has a surprising history of noise complaints.
history: The foundation was laid on March 22nd 1891 in remembrance of the birthday of its name giver German Emperor Wilhelm I. (March 22nd 1797 – March 9th 1888).
Church, around 1900
Build following the designs of Franz Schwechten, the church was opened on September 1st 1895.
Building costs converted into today’s currency: 45 million Euro
The building with its five towers reached a height of 113m making it one of the largest buildings in Charlottenburg, which, but back in the day, used to be an independent city.
Of those 113m, only 68m are left today.
Close-up, 1954
In the night of November 23rd 1943 the church was bombed heavily by the British air force. The damage was substantial: The roof timbering collapsed which made the top of the main tower break off.
Architect Egon Eiermann designed the new Kaiser Wilhelm Memory Church. The damaged main tower stayed in its original state making the church a memorable sight.
Berliners like to call the church “Hollow Tooth” or “Lipstick and Powder Box”.

Since January 28th 2008 three clocks on the tower don’t work anymore due to “damage beyond repair”. Their hands were positioned permanently on midnight/noon. Only the clock on the east side of the church shows the correct time.
qi: The five church bells of the old Memory Church caused quite a stir back in their days. Wolves living in the nearby Zoo were disturbed by the noise they made during evening prayer and started to howl uncontrollably.
look_out: Inside the church you can find a small museum.
StalingradMadonna
The “Stalingrad Madonna” is a drawing done around Christmas of the year 1942 by German doctor Kurt Reuber. It is exhibited inside the church.
The “Nail Cross of Coventry“ is made of nails that were part of the Coventry Cathedral. During World War II German air raids completely destroyed the house of worship.
next_stop: Only 750m to the next stop, Beireuther Straße.

stopInfo.title: BayreutherStr/ SchillStr
teaser: This street shows its ugly face at night. Do you want to know the funny nickname some of the prostitutes got themselves over the years and why this is most definitely not a paradise for shopping?
history: The Kurfürstenstraße was first built by the end of the 17th century and until 1863 used to be called Mühlenstraße.
During Nazi times the house with the address Kurfürstenstraße 115/116 was used as a so called “Jew Departement”. From here the deportation of European Jews into the concentration camps was organised.
Eichmannreferat
Today you can find a memorial plaque where the house used to be.
qi: The Ladies of the Night offer their services come rain or shine. That fact earned them the nickname “Frostitutes” a couple of winters back.
look_out: Please do not confuse this street with the popular shopping mile Kurfürstendamm!
By daytime those bus stops don’t look like much but they go along the famous Kurfürstenstraße.
At nightfall the Kurfürstenstraße becomes a hot-spot for street prostitution. Here you can look into the abyss of the milieu.
next_stop: Lützowplatz is 500m walk from Schillstraße.

pois.title: Stehende & liegende Gruppe / Standing & Laying Group
Tangentiale Berührung und Treppenskulptur / Axial Touch and Stairway

stopInfo.title: Lützowplatz
teaser: You have now reached the Lützowplatz, a square for cows and pretentious musicians to enjoy alike.
Did you ever wonder what genius had the idea to turn Austrian Adolf Hitler into a German? Here are some very interesting answers:
history: The square was named after Baron Ludwig Adolf Wilhelm von Lützow, a Prussian general, 35 years after his death on 23rd 1869. He used to live nearby.
Another resident of the area was Carl Andreas Julius Bolle, the owner of a famous dairy factory. In the years of 1880 he would let some of his cattle pasture on the area today known as Lützowplatz.
Hercules bridge, around 1900
After the “Hercules Bridge” was built in 1890 the square had a connection to the famous park Tiergarten and therefore grew in importance.

Shortly after lots of concerts would be given on the square which attracted famous composers such as Johannes Brahms, Antonín Dvořák und Max Bruch. The Lützowplatz rose to be the musical centre of Berlin at the time.
Hercules bridge, 2017

During Wold War II the square was home to an air defence station which made it a much sought after target for bombings and ultimately led to the destruction of most of the houses in the area including the “Hercules Bridge”. It was later replaced by a three car lane pre-stressed concrete bridge.
qi: A possible reason for the massive bombing of the Lützowplatz could be the address Lützowplatz Nr. 11. Here, Austrian born Adolf Hitler was granted German citizenship by lawyer Anton Franzen on February 25th 1932. For a short time in 1934 Hitler had his offices just around the corner, at the riverbank Lützowufer.
look_out: There are six pieces of art to be found on the Lützowplatz.
Hercules and the Erymanthian Boar
The bronze sculpture “Hercules and the Erymanthian Boar”  was created in 1904 by Louis Tuaillon and brought to the Lützowplatz in 1967.
Standing and Laying Group, Sabina Grzimek“Standing and Laying Group” (1980-1985) by artist Sabina Grzimek. The statues were erected in 1995.
Axial Touch Sculpture, Volkmar Haase“Axial Touch and Stairway Sculpture” by artist Volkmar Haase (1988).
In 1990 three more sculptures were added during a symposium for sculptors. They were placed at the north end of the square.
Torblock, Volker BartschVolker Bartsch, Torblock, Reinersreuther Granite /Steel
3-X-90, Ernst AltesErnst Altes, 3-X-90 in Deutschland, Quartz /Steel
Unknown title , Udo G. CordesUdo G. Cordes, Title unknown
next_stop: It’s just 500 metres to the Nordic Embassies.

stopInfo.title: Nordic Embassies
teaser: Behind this bilious green facade are hiding the embassies of Scandinavia. You couldn’t care less? Think again! Especially in the rain a little miracle awaits you:
history: The copper band encloses five national chancelleries.
The uniform structure symbolises the cooperation between Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Iceland and Finland.
The copper building was designed by the Austrian-Finish architecture firm of Alfred Berger and Tiina Parkkinen.
Construction started in May 1997 end took two years. The cost were a whopping 49,5 Million Euro.
The Danish embassy sports a glass facade.
The lamellae made of made of larch wood belong to the Finish embassy.
Sweden’s embassy is made of glass fronts and limestone from Gotland.
The red rhyolite belongs to the embassy of Iceland.
The facade of Norway’s embassy is 15m high, weighs 150 tons and is made of granite that is 900 Million years old.
The ambassadors of the different countries do not live in the buildings. Their residences can be found all over Berlin.
qi: The diplomatic relations between the Nordic countries and Germany were quite frosty for a long time after World War II. The war between Norway and the Federal Republic of Germany for example was officially ended in 1951, six years after most of the European countries had declared peace already.
The backyard of the Nordic Embassies is completely tree free. The ground is made of slate that contains a lot of iron. Therefore it lights up rusty and golden after rain showers.
look_out: The Felleshus (Community House) is open for visitors. Its facade is made of Maple wood, exposed concrete, glass and Swedish marble.
Regular exhibitions and conventions draw visitors in. They can go for a special lunch at the cafeteria, a Nordic restaurant.
The waterfronts between the buildings symbolise the Nordic Sea.
Photo opportunity?
Angel wings. Ask a friend or a stranger to take your photo!
next_stop: The next stop is 700m. Walk along TierGarten forest or jump back on the bus.

stopInfo.title: Victory Column
teaser: Welcome to the Großer Stern! Every day more than a 180.000 cars make their hectic way through the famous roundabout. But let’s be honest: Only the Victory Column in the centre of the square is really important. Why one could see the monument as an architectural middle finger to France, Denmark and Austria?
history: The Großer Stern was built in the name of elector Friedrich III., the future King of Prussia, as a so called Jagstern. A Jagstern helps dividing different hunting districts.
Until the beginning of the 19th century the Großer Stern was surrounded by various sandstone sculptures called “The Dolls”.
Aerial view of the Siegessäule
Every day more than 180.000 cars rush through the roundabout. Please do use the pedestrian lights if you don’t want the next stop on our tour to be the hospital.
From 1996 until 2003 this is where the closing rally of the famous rave Love Parade would happen.

On July 24th 2008 future president Barack Obama gave a speech in front of 200.000 people. He was originally scheduled to speak in front of the Brandenburg Gate but that landmark is reserved for heads of state and not  presidential candidates.
qi: The Mexican monument ”El Ángel de la Independencia”, which was commissioned in 1902, bares a suspicious resemblance to the Victory Column in Berlin. We let you run check the numbers and decide for yourself who nicked the design from whom…
look_out: Use the tunnels to get to the Großer Stern. The motion sensitive lights are fun but the buskers can be a bit loud!

Over the years many repairs happened. Still bullet holes can be found in the red granite of which the socket of the Victory Column is made. They were left there as a reminder after Wold War 2 intentionally.
next_stop: Seriously, don’t bother going back to the bus. Our next stop is just 300m away!
extra: The Victory Column with a height of 69 metres is a definite eye catcher. It was built from 1865 until 1873 and designed by Johann Heinrich Strack. It commemorates the military victories against Denmark, Austria and France.
Original location opposite the Reichstag
Its original location was the Königsplatz, which today is called Platz der Republik and right opposite the Reichstag building. Berliners call the Victory Column lovingly “Goldelse”.
The golden statue on top of the column represents the goddess of victory. It was designed by Friedrich Drake, is 8,32m tall and wears a helmet with eagle wings.
Victoria Goldelse Siegessaeule
Victoria seemingly likes to accessorise with a Laurel wreath, a standard and an iron cross.
Her likeness is pretty much nicked from Victoria of Great Britain and Ireland, who at the time was crown princess of Prussia and therefore an important influence.
View from the platform
Check the numbers: It is exactly 285 stairs up to the top!
Understandably France wanted to blast the Victory Column after Wold War 2 as it is a reminder of the bitter defeat against Prussia in 1870/1871.
To make matters worse: The golden cannons outside the Victory Column are originals from the battlefields of the Franco-Prussian War.

January 15th 1991 a group called “Revolutionary Cell” bombed the Victory Column. Thankfully no one was hurt, because the explosives on the observation platform failed to detonate completely. The repairs took more than ten months.

stopInfo.title: Bellevue Palace
teaser: Did you ever wonder, how the Federal President of Germany lives? Two rooms, a kitchen and a bath? The head of state made himself at home in this “humble” abode. But be very aware! The lease very often comes with a time stamp.
history: The castle which name translated to „Beautiful view“ and its beautiful white facade were built in 1786 as a private residence of Ferdinand of Prussia. Just one of the many perks of being the youngest brother of Frederick the Great (King of Prussia).
The two storey building sports a neoclassical style and is divided in three wings. Architect: Philipp Daniel Boumann.
Bellevue, 1818
The last German emperor, Wilhelm II. (1888-1918), lived here.
After countless renovations only the ballroom on the upper floor is in its original state.
Offices, Bellevue with Moabit behind
The building with the black granite facade and the massive glass roof south of the castle doesn’t quite fit in but still belongs to Bellevue. It houses offices.
In April 1941 the castle was hit by countless incendiary bombs and nearly burnt down to the ground. Architect Carl-Heinz Schwennicke brought it back to its former glory in 1959.

What used to be living quarters today is office space. This fact makes Bellevue a bluff package. The Federal President of Germany for many years now doesn’t actually live in the castle anymore. His residence is in Berlin-Dahlem. Only his offices remain in Bellevue. So don’t get too excited!
qi: You can book guides at Bellevue. This has to happen months in advance and you will be very likely be fooled again. Don’t bother! Many of the rooms open to visitors are staged. The alleged office of the President for example isn’t actually the place where the Bundespräsident goes about his daily business. That really happens a couple of doors down at the end of a dark corridor.
Schloß Bellevue, around 1948
Shortly after World War 2 Bellevue looked rotten and burnt down. It was used as a soup kitchen for the poorest of the poor at this time. No glamour there!
look_out: Bellevue must not be confused with the Buckingham Palace. The flag being raised does not necessarily mean the President is in the building. In reality there are just three reasons for the flag to be taken down:
If the President has left the country on official business.
If the President is at its second location of office in Bonn.
If the President has official business elsewhere in Germany and stays there overnight.
next_stop: House of the Cultures of the World is a 800m walk along the river. Remember: You can always go back to the bus!

stopInfo.title: House of the World's Cultures
teaser: The building was meant as a gift from the US. Why most Berliners take the piss concerning its architecture and what terrible accident cost the life of a 27 year old journalist on May 21th 1980.
history: The House of the Cultures of the World was built in 1957 and designed specifically as a contribution to the International Construction Exhibit “Interbau”. Its design is supposed to represent freedom and unrestricted exchange of ideas.

The former convention hall was given the nickname “Pregnant Oyster”. If you have a look from the riverside of the building you can make an educated guess to why. Architect to blame is Hugh Stubbins. Today, mostly international contemporary art is exhibited.
The roof consists of a net made of steel rope which is hung by two massive steel arches. The gaps are filled with concrete.

Construction and planning of the Building were flawed. On May 21th 1980 the south side of the roof collapsed. Five people in the atrium were injured and 27 year old Hartmut Küster died in a hospital six days after the accident.
Important US presidents like John F. Kennedy (1963) and Jimmy Carter (1978) held speeches here and more than 1.000 people can fit in the auditorium.
qi: Image from film Æon Flux
Because of its futuristic style the House of the Cultures of the World was site of many movies. The most famous being “Æon Flux“ (2005) starring Charlize Theron.
look_out: Right in the middle of the so called “Mirror Lake” you will find a bronze plastic called “Large Divided Oval: Butterfly“. It weighs more than eight tonnes and was bought in 1986 for a whopping 3,5 Million Mark which made it one of the most expensive art purchases of its time.
Large Butterfly sculpture , Henry Moore

The sculpture was designed by Britain’s very own Henry Moores. The “Butterfly” is his last public work. A letter asking Moores to donate the sculpture to the House of the Cultures of the World was never answered. The artist died on August 31st 1986 forcing the foundation to buy the plastic. Experts are convinced that Henry Moores would have been more than happy to donate the sculpture. Bad luck! For everyone involved…
next_stop: In 500m a unique selfie opportunity will present itself. Bus or stroll, it’s up to you!

pois.title: Ermordete Reichstagsabgeordnete / Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag

stopInfo.title: Square of the Republic
teaser: You want a selfie with the famous Reichstag in the background or simply a relaxed picnic on one of Berlin’s most historic green spaces? Then get off the bloody bus now!
history: The square was built in 1730 and used mostly for parades under King Frederick William IV of Prussia.

On December 18th 1864 the square was renamed “King’s Square”. After that the Germans pretty much started playing name ping pong: From 1926 until 1933 the area was again known as Square of the Republic, because no one wanted anything to to with Kings anymore during times of Weimar Republic. When Hitler rose to power he wanted the square to be called “King’s Square”. After the End of World War 2 it today is known as “Square of the Republic” again. But for how long until some genius will rename it again? At least we know the two choices.
Raczynski Palace, demolished 1884
The construction of the Reichstag didn’t start until 1884. The square therefore was here first.
Original location opposite the Reichstag
Do you remember the Victory Column from three stops ago? We hope so! It used to be standing right here on the square.
qi: Michael Jackson performed an open air concert on the Square of the Republic on 1988.
During summer months the grassland on the square is used by Berliners as an open air BBQ location. Its illegal but still…
The parking areas left and right of the square are used as training grounds for driving students because of its low traffic density.

On July 22nd 2005 a bright red microlight aircraft crashed into the square. It was not, as first feared, a terrorist attack but a man with suicidal intentions. The pilot, whose name was never made public out of respect for his two children, had bludgeoned his wife, hidden her body in the cellar and out of remorse killed himself.
look_out: Reunification flag
On the night of German Reunification, October 2nd 1990, a 6m high and 10m wide flag was raised on the square. It has remained there every day since.
Names and dates of the monument

The Memorial to the Murdered Members of the Reichstag commemorates the 96 members of the parliament who died unnaturally between 1933 and 1945. It is made of 96 cast iron plates, with the names, birth and death dates and places engraved on the edges and has been designed to be extended if new names are discovered in the future
next_stop: The Reichstag is just 200m away. You can see it right there. Seriously, you can walk it. I believe in you!

attractions.hours: Daily: 8am - 12pm. Last dome entrance: 10pm with prior registration

stopInfo.title: Reichstag
teaser: You don’t fancy an avalanche of dry facts but are rather interested in some less known info about the home of the German Federal Parliament?
B-Town has found some rather cool stories about the secret tunnel system under the Reichstag and has an absolute insider tip-off on how to skip the massive queue in front of the building.
history: Too many to list but here are some important ones. Check the Wikipedia link above for more information.
Building the Reichstag, 1888
Building the Reichstag started in 1884 and finished 1894. Architect: Paul Wallot
Architectural elements: A bit of everything really. Renaissance, Baroque and Classicism.
Reichstag glass dome
The glass dome is 23.5m high, 28m wide, 1.200 tons and covered with 3.000 square metres of glass: Architect Sir Norman Foster.
Important historical happenings synopsis:
The afternoon of November 9th 1918 politician Philipp Scheidemann declared Germany as a Republic from one of the balconies.
Reichstag fire
On February 27th 1933 the famous Reichstag fire nearly completely destroyed the dome and the plenary assembly hall.
Red Army at the Reichstag
On April 30th 1945 the red flag of the former Soviet Union is raised on top of the Reichstag and becomes a symbol for the fall of the Third Reich.
Dem Deutschen Volke
The inscription “Dem Deutschen Volke“ means something along the lines of „To the German people“ and was chiselled in 1916.
The construction cost 24 million Mark back in the days. That’s a whopping 159 Million Euro in today’s currency.
The Reichstag has its own power plant.
Its tempting to say that the construction of the Reichstag was paid for by the French, The money needed to build it came from the war reparations from the French after they lost the war of 1870/1871.
qi: In the summer of 1995 the artists Christo and Jeanne-Claude wrapped the Reichstag in a 100.000 square metre big silver cover for two weeks. Inside the building you can visit a permanent exhibition showing drafts, plans and models of the project.

Underground the Reichstag there is a labyrinth of tunnels hidden. The official plans for them are not public record. Of course. But more than one contemporary witness has spoken out about the tunnels in the past. One of the tunnels for example under passing the west side of Wilhelmstraße starting at the Ministry of Agriculture along the Palais of the former President of the Reich, the Ministry of Interior and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs ending underneath the old Chancellery of the Reich.

Dr. Hans-Otto Meissner was the son of Otto Meissner a National Socialist state official living at the Palais of the former President of the Reich for years. He wrote in his memoir:-nl-“Because of the many rats down there, crawling through the tunnels was considered a test of courage for us kids at the time. In the coal cellar of the former Chancellery of the Reich you could find a hatch that was covered by an iron tile. That was our door to the sub terrestrial labyrinth under the Reichstag.”
look_out: The Reichstag is surrounded by four towers with countless ornaments and statues. Are you touring in a group? Then let your friends have a guess while you already know what topics the towers are dedicated to.
Use the map above to show which towers are which. If you haven't found the map yet, just click the top image or rotate your device.
The Northwest-Tower -b2-Trade and shipping -b2-Big industry -b2-Small businesses -b2-Electrical engineering
The Northeast-Tower -b2-Education -b2-Teaching -b2-Art -b2-Literature
The Southeast-Tower -b2-Defence power ashore -b2-Defence power on land -b2-Administration of justice -b2-Statecraft
The Southwest-Tower -b2-Agriculture -b2-Farming -b2-Viniculture -b2-Brewery

Unfortunately the Reichstag is no good for spontaneous people. Because of the ever growing terror panic over the years it has become necessary to register and show some form if ID before entering the building. On the right hand side of the entrance you can find an Information-Pavilion. This is where you can book a guide through the Reichstag.

Travel smart and skip the line? If you get a reservation in the restaurant on the rooftop of the Reichstag you can skip the line. Unfortunately you still have to show your ID and make the reservation 24 hours in advance. Use the web link or telephone number above to book
next_stop: It’s less than 500m to the Brandenburg Gate and the bus is likely to take longer than walking
extra: A little something between stops if you prefer to walk.
Memorial to the Sinti and Roma Victims

The Memorial to the Sinti and Roma Victims of National Socialism is a monument dedicated to the memory of the 220,000 – 500,000 people murdered in the Nazi genocide of the European Sinti and Roma peoples.
Information boards surround the memorial and provide a chronology of the genocide of the Sinti and Roma.

pois.title: See where the Wall originally lay

stopInfo.title: Brandenburg Gate
teaser: The lady governing the quadriga on top of the former city gate was dressed much more revealingly until 1994. Why today’s statue is only a copy of the once so wonderfully naked original?
history: East and the West border
The Gate became a symbol for the German reunification. It was the border between the East and the West before 1991.
It was built from Sandstone (1788 until 1791) and is a fine example for German Neoclassic. The architect Carl Gotthard Langhan’s design was inspired by the Greek Acropolis.

The gate was originally meant to give the lush street “Unter den Linden” a plush finish. The quadriga (designed by Johann Gottfried Schadow) was put on top of the Gate later in 1793. Napoleon then “abducted” the quadriga and took it to Paris 1806 after defeating Prussia in battle. Eight years later it was recaptured.
Brandenburg Gate, Wold War II
During Wold War II the Quadriga was damaged so heavily that it was disposed and replaced by a copy in 1956.
The five passages are divided by six Doric columns and 11m (36 feet) wide crossbars. The Brandenburg Gate is 26m (85 feet) high and 64m (213 feet) wide.
qi: The rumour of the quadriga facing different directions according to different occasions is hard to shake. However every picture and historic depiction shows the horses facing east.

Still some historians insist that the carriage was turned around for a couple of days when Benito Mussolini visited Berlin in 1937. Officials wanted to avoid the leader of the National Fascist Party being greeted “by four horse arses”. Proof for that little anecdote unfortunately does not exist.
look_out: Have a closer look at the lady on top of the Gate:
Eirene
Originally she portrayed Eirene, the Greek goddess of peace.
After getting the quadriga back from the French, the people used her as a symbol of the goddess of victory and triumph (Nike).
She used to be naked but got a dress in 1994 because Eirene looked “stiff and bleak” from behind.
Iron Cross, oak wreath and Prussian eagle
Celebrating the victory over Napoleon the wand after returning to the Brandenburg Gate was pimped with an Iron Cross encircled by an oak wreath and a Prussian eagle.
next_stop: The next bus stop on our tour is called “Unter den Linden/Friedrichstraße”. It is only 750m away from where you are now. Should you decide to walk the distance you can have a look at the world’s famous Hotel Adlon and the Russian Embassy on the right hand of the street.

pois.title: check the fight event - Kronenstraße is 600m away

stopInfo.title: Unter den Linden
