teaser: Had enough of historical facts and dates? Welcome to Berlin’s youngest shopping mile! Yet even the Friedrichstraße has a long and sometimes even dark and twisted past. Read more about it while you sip on a Cappuccino and show your friends the contents of your shopping bags:
history: The street is named after the King of Prussia, former Elector Prince Friedrich III.

Here some shopping highlights to get started:-b2-Dussmann KulturKaufhaus (a massive luxury Mall in Friedrichstraße 90)-b2-Birkenstock (Friedrichstraße 153A)-b2-Esprit (Friedrichstraße 88)-b2-Timberland (Friedrichstraße 94)-b2-Fossil (Friedrichstraße 96)-b2-Lacoste (Friedrichstraße 158 -164)-b2-Hugo Boss (Friedrichstraße 165)-b2-H&M store (Friedrichstraße 79-89).

Anything the men could fancy in the meantime?-b2-The spectacular show rooms of the Volkswagen Group are located in Friedrichstraße 84. Dashing sports cars and the latest limousines are waiting to be goggled at.
After the shopping high ready for some more history?

Adored as the area of the rich and famous for many years, Friedrichstraße descended to crime and darkness around the turn of the 20th century. Gold and gemstones were traded on the black market and prostitution flourished. Not so posh now, hey!
qi: The Friedrichstraße used to simply be called “Crossroad” until Elector Prince Frederick III was said to have complained: “What do you mean by Crossroad? It needs a proper name. Something like mine.”

With a maximum width of 17m the Friedrichstraße has always been very narrow. At the beginning of the 20th century hackneys, automobiles, hand-drawn carts, buses, bicycles and pedestrians crowded the street. For this reason on December 21th 1902 one of the first policeman in the world was stationed as a traffic warden with a police whistle on the corner of Friedrichstraße/ Unter den Linden.
look_out: At the corner of Friedrichstraße and Kronenstraße you will find a commemorative plaque in memory of the March Revolution of 1848.
March Revolution memorial

Bloody street fights between the military and civilians from March 17th to March 18th and cost the lives of 50 soldiers and more than 200 civilians. King Frederick William IV drew back his troops by midnight and stopped an even bigger bloodbath from happening.
next_stop: The Staatsoper (state opera) is within spitting distance. In 400 metres another black hole for millions of the tax payer’s money, just like the much maligned BrandenburgAirport, awaits Berliners and tourists alike.

stopInfo.title: Berlin State Opera
teaser: Berlin has yet another black hole for tax payer’s money! The Berlin State Opera has a lot of things to offer… just not at the moment! For the last seven years, the Opera is housed in a building across town. Believe it or not, this has nothing to do with the war. What exactly went wrong?
history: Berliners like to call the State Opera Lindenoper, which translates to Opera under the lime tree.
Berlin Opera, 1745
The Opera was built from 1741 to 1743 according to the plans of Georg Wenzeslaus von Knobelsdorff as part of the so called Forum Fridericianum.
The building is divided into the Apollo Saloon (featuring a banquet hall and a foyer), the Theater Saloon (auditorium and ballroom) and the Corinthian Saloon (featuring the stage and music room).

The Berlin State Opera featured many famous first performances such as: Carl Maria von Weber’s „The Marksman” (June 18th 1821), Otto Nicolai’s „The Merry Wives of Windsor“ (March 9th 1849), Alban Berg‘s „Wozzeck“ (December 4th 1925)
During times of National Socialism former Prime Minister Hermann Göring decided over the fate of the Opera. He completely banned Jewish singers, musicians and crew members.
Schillertheater in Charlottenburg

On October 3rd 2010 the whole ensemble moved to the Schillertheater in Charlottenburg across town due to renovations. Three years of building time and a budget of 239 million Euro were estimated at the time.
Today Berlin is looking at 400 Million already and an Opera that is still far from being reopened.
qi: The night of August 19th 1843 the Opera burned down completely. The king decided it should be reopened a year later.-nl-Following the design of architect Carl Ferdinand Langhans the State Opera was rebuilt in little more than a year.-nl-Today’s designers, planners, architects and engineers could really take a page out of their books. What worked without a hitch in 1843 seems to be Mission Impossible in 2017.

Since the fire the State Opera seems to have its very own ghost story. According to urban legend the ghost of a young opera songstress strays through the dark tunnels under the stage looking for her long lost (and probably badly burnt) love. Whether the ghost of the Opera moved to the Schillertheater too is unclear.
look_out: FRIDERICUS REX APOLLINI ET MUSIS

In the mid 1980's the Opera was renovated once before. The sign “Deutsche Staatsoper” was replaced by the Latin inscription “FRIDERICUS REX APOLLINI ET MUSIS” which means: “King Frederick dedicates this building to Apollo and the Muses.”
next_stop: The next 650m will cruise along the Humboldt University, the river Spree, the armoury and the Crown Prince Palace. Alternatively you could go back to the bus station and wait for the Number 100 to bring you to our next stop, the “Lustgarten”.

stopInfo.title: Lust Garden
teaser: It’s time for more selfies and a refreshing beer in one off the most historic gardens of Berlin! Welcome to the Lustgarten. Since the 16th century people have been regularly misbehaving in the hidden pavilions on the grounds.
history: The Lustgarten is part of the famous Berlin Museum Island [tour coming soon] and is located on what used to be a massive wetland. The area was originally part of the City Castle which today can be found on the other side of the street.
The Park was first mentioned in 1471 when it was used as a large herbal garden.
In 1646 the botanic chaos was brought some order by royal gardener Michael Hanf and master gardener Johann Sigismund Elßholtz. The duo constructed the Lustgarten following several Dutch prototypes.
In 1652 for the first time in Berlin tomatoes and potatoes (weird exotic plants from the New World at the time) were planted in the Lustgarten.
King Frederick William I of Prussia loved his army and didn’t much care for gardens. He leveled the area in 1713 and turned it into a parade ground with no plants whatsoever.
On February 7th 1933 more than 200.000 Germans protested against Reich Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his politics in the Lustgarten. Shortly after, public opposition to the party was banned.
In 1934, Lustgarten was converted to host mass rallies of up to 1 million people.
Olympic Games procession, 1936

Air raids by the Allied Forces destroyed most of the Museum Island but mostly spared the Lustgarten. A renovation of the Lustgarten from 1998 until 1999 cost Berlin a whopping 3,5 Million Euro and won the Price for German Landscape Architecture in 2001.
qi: Lustgarten

The Lustgarten was very true to its own name over the centuries. Kings and important heads of states are said to have indulged in extramarital fun with their mistresses or prostitutes in one of the many pavilions and hidden corners on the grounds.
look_out: Herbert Baum memorial

Freedom fighter Herbert Baum (February 10th 1912 – June 11th 1942) was one of the men responsible for the arson attack on the Lustgarten on March 18th 1942 protesting an exhibition there called “The Soviet Paradis”. Baum and his co-conspirators were denunciated, arrested immediately and shortly after sentenced to death. Since 1981 a memorial stone remembers the “Resistance Group Baum”. It was never determined whether Herbert Baum died from his injuries suffered during torture or whether he committed suicide.
Stadtschloss, between 1890 und 1900

The red granite bowl with its 22 foot diameter was created by mason Christian Gottlieb Cantian who used a single block of granite found in a boulder just outside Berlin. Since 1831 the bowl is a regular constituent of the Lustgarten even though its location has changed a lot over the years.
next_stop: Passing the Berlin Dom the 600m long walk brings us to the Marienkirche, the next stop on our tour. On the bridge leading over the river Spree street merchants sell the famous fur hats popular in Russia in the past. But look out! Some of them are made by dog and cat fur. A cognition that brought on a small scandal in Berlin a couple of years ago.
If you skip the bus, maybe stop by the Radisson Blu for a drink in the bar for a view, inside and out, of the world’s largest cylindrical aquarium.
Radisson Blu aquarium
Known as the AquaDom, it contains 1 million litres of salt water and 1,500 tropical fish from over 110 different species. The elevator goes through the center of the aquarium for a unique viewpoint.
extra: Berliner Dom
Check the Museum Island tour for more information about the Berliner Dom>

stopInfo.title: Marienkirche
teaser: The Marienkirche is home to the „Most beautiful organ of Berlin” and the creepy fresco “Dance of the Dead”. Under its roof religious superstars like Martin Luther King have preached to their congregation. Also the Marienkirche was crime scene to the “Murder of the Century” in Berlin.
history: This Protestant church is the oldest (sacred used) parish church of Berlin. The earliest mentions are January 3rd 1292. The  tower is 48m high and the church is built in the Baroque style.
After air raids during Wold War II destroyed most of the city, Marienkirche was one of the only mainline churches in use.
“The Dance with the Dead” reconstruction

“The Dance with the Dead” fresco is 22,6m long and 2m high. It can be found inside the church and constitutes as one of the oldest artworks of the Middle Ages. The mural painting most likely has its origins in 1484, a year in which the plague reigned over Berlin.

Ooops! During the Reformation times „The Dance with the Dead“ was likely covered in whitewash and only rediscovered in 1861. The fresco is in danger of fading due to wet brickwork and is protected by a glass wall.
Marienkirche Altar
The Gothic baptismal font in front of the altar in the middle of the choir is made of bronze and dates back to 1437.
Organ in the Marienkirche
“Berlin’s most beautiful organ” was built from 1720 until 1723 by Joachim Wagner. In 1800 Friedrich Falckenhagen removed 1.400 of the 2.556 original organ pipes thinking they were “redundant”.
qi: On September 13th 1964 Nobel Peace Prize winner Martin Luther King preached in the Marienkirche. He on that day also uttered the sentence: “No man-built wall can separate God's children.”
look_out: The conciliation cross on the west side of the Marienkirche is a constant reminder that Berliners are not to be fucked with.
On August 16th 1324 provost Nicolaus of Bernau was beaten to death by an angry mob because he wouldn’t stop preaching that their ways were bound for hell.
Admittedly annoying his murder was considered most uncalled for. For 700 years Berlin and everyone living here was basically excommunicated.
Marienkirche conciliation cross
In 1726 the conciliation cross (first made of wood, later from stone) was erected as a big fat SORRY for the brutal murder.

On top of that Berliners had to pay a massive reconciliation fee and met for many years for a memorial service in honour of Nicolaus of Bernau. Finally the church forgave Berlin for the “Murder of the Century”.
next_stop: It’s just a few metres to Alexanderplatz and the famous TV Tower. A walk passing the famous Fountain of Neptune, especially in summer, gives you a very nice feeling of Berlin flair. Or are you sick and tired of walking? No problem. Just go back on the bus 100 and it will drive you straight to the Alex.

stopInfo.title: Alexanderplatz
teaser: Why the Alexanderplatz used to be called „The Devil’s Pleasure Garden“ during the 13th century and what sad and shocking history hides in the tunnels under the Alex? Read all about it here:
history: Alex (as Berliners call it) used to be named King’s Door Square (“Königs Tor Platz”) from 1701 until 1805. King Frederick Wilhelm III. gave it it’s new name honouring a state visit of Russian Czar Alexander in 1805.

In the 13th century the area, at the time being outside the city walls, was known as „The Devil’s Pleasure Garden“. Just a few merchants lived at what today is known as the Alexanderplatz. Right next to the houses the gallows were situated. Go figure!
Alexanderplatz was regularly used as a parade ground. During the March Revolution in 1848 the square saw countless bloody street fights.
Demonstration, 1989

On October 7th 1989 a couple of thousand Berliners met in front of the World Time Clock for a peaceful protest. The police cracked down hard on the crowd arresting 1.200 people. 33 days later the Berlin Wall came down once and for all.

During the 1790ies seven three story houses were built on Alexanderplatz. One of them home to the famous hotel “The Deer’s In” (“Zum Hirschen”) in which literary idol of German Romantic Heinrich von Kleist lived his last days until his suicide on November 21st 1811.
TV tower close-up
The TV Tower [EXTRA] is built at the centre of the Alexanderplatz and is as high as 77 giraffes stacked on top of each other.
LOXX Zoologischer Garten
In the nearby shopping Mall “Alexa” the world’s biggest model railway showing the whole of Berlin in miniature.
Every day more than 360.000 people cross Alexanderplatz.
qi: Under the Alexanderplatz a massive tunnel system and countless bunkers are hiding in the darkness. The biggest bunker was built from 1941 until 1943.

Just a few hours before the official end of the war on May 2nd 1945 German troops blasted the southwest tunnel under the Landwehr canal trying to stop the Russian Army advancing further into the city. Following the explosion the complete tunnel system was flooded. Hundreds of people hiding in the bunkers were killed in the process.
look_out: The World Time Clock, Alexanderplatz
The World Time Clock is 10m high, 16 tons heavy and revolves around itself once a minute.
The 24 sides are according to the 24 main time zones of the world. The clock has 148 city names written on it and until today is a famous meeting point for Berliners as well as tourists.
Brunnen der Völkerfreundschaft
The „Fountain of Friendship between Nations (“Brunnen der Völkerfreundschaft“) was designed by an art collection under the lead of Artist Walter Womacka and opened on October 7th 1970.
The water basin is 23m in diameter, 6,20m high and made of glass, ceramic, and grated copper.
next_stop: Done already! This tour through Berlin is unfortunately over. Have another beer or maybe an ice cream while scrolling through our gallery and find another interesting tour, discovering facts about Berlin that just Berliners know.
View from Radisson Berlin, Alexanderplatz

One last stop. The Park Inn by Radisson Berlin Alexanderplatz has a roof terrace offering fantastic views across the city. Its 4€ to get in and open until 10pm in the summer. Have a drink, a little relax and let us know if you enjoyed the tour.

stopInfo.title: Television Tower
teaser: Ever wondered how the windows are cleaned on this 368m high tower? We have the answer for you
history: The TV Tower is 368m high and therefore the highest building in Germany.
There are two elevators for visitors. A third one exists but is reserved only for technical personal.
The elevator needs 38 seconds to reach the vista floor in 203 meters.
The design was inspired by the soviet satellite Sputnik 1.
qi: The TV Tower did not have the necessary paperwork in order when the construction started. That is the reason why there never was an official start of construction. Therefore the tower strictly speaking started as an illegal building site.
The pope’s Revenge

The pope’s Revenge: The Tower caused a lot of headache and embarrassment for the GDR authorities because the steel sphere below the antenna produced the reflection of a giant cross. Jokingly this was understood as the Pope's revenge on the secular socialist state for having removed crucifixes from churches at the time.
look_out: If weather allows tourists can look out up to 60km (37 miles, 19.6850 foot, 65.617 yards).
The restaurant makes one full turn every 30 minutes.
The TV Tower sways up to 15cm (6 inches) and can withstand winds up to 133km per hour (83 mph)
The sphere is surrounded by four guide trails which are used for cleaning.

Two more trails are solely used for cleaning the windows of the vista. You can see them above and underneath the windows. Rope access technicians take over this dangerous job by abseiling from the trails.

tours.tourDesc: One island, five museums, six thousand years of history
tourBrief: On this tour we’ll introduce you to all five big museums on the Island as well as some unexpected facts concerning the Berliner Dom.
Insider-Nuggets and amusing anecdotes from history will turn this Tour into an interesting adventure through time.

attractions.busStop: What to expect from this tour?

stopInfo.title: A little Introduction
teaser: Did you know that Museum Island became the site of a spectacular robbing worth millions in 2017 and that noblemen and women have been misbehaving here since the early 16th century?
Interested? Pull on your boots and join us for another B-Town adventure!
history: The Museum Island on the north tip of the Spree Island is part of the Historic Middle of Berlin and was declared UNESCO World Heritage in 1999.
Scale model of island
The five main museums mainly show archaeological collections and 19th century art.
The buildings belong to one of the most important museum complexes of the world. But they offer much more than just boring theory.

If you can’t afford the entrance to the different museums, don’t worry. You will not have to suffer from boredom. We have collected lots of interesting facts concerning the different statues, sculptures and artworks that can be found in the area of the Lustgarten.
While the historic core of Berlin on the south side of the island kept flourishing the area on which the Museum Island is located today was neglected as some sort of simple garden for a long time.
It was only during the 18th century that King Frederick William II of Prussia followed the suggestion of archaeologist Aloys Hirt and started the planning for a conversion.
In 1810 the planning of a pubic ‘well selected art collection’ was finally on their way.
Karl Friedrich Schinkel published first plans for the new construction in 1822 while Wilhelm von Humboldt became head of the commission for the building of the Museum Island.
Altes Museum, prior to 1854
In 1830 the Alte Museum (Old Museum) was opened and became the first public museum of Prussia.
The Royal Prussian Museum which today is called the Neue Museum followed in 1859.
Alte Nationalgalerie, 1891
1876 the National Gallery (Alte Nationalgalerie) opened for the public.
Bode-Museum and Monbijou Bridge, 1904
In 1904 the Kaiser-Friedrich-Museum was built. Since 1956 it is called Bode-Museum honouring art historian Wilhelm von Bode. He for many years was the general manager for all five museums.
On the tip of the island the Pergamonmuseum finally opened its doors in 1930.
During Nazi times architect Albert Speer planned countless monumental new builds in the Museum Island. There however were never realised.
Das Bode Museum, 1945

Air strikes destroyed more than 70 percent of the buildings during World War II. After that the island became part of East Germany. In the 50ies the reconstruction of the Museum Island started slowly.
After the Germany’s reunification the rebuilding finally picked up speed. Up until today the construction hasn’t finished which explains the countless scaffolds in the area.
qi: In March 2017 one of the most spectacular art robberies of Berlin took place at the Bode-Museum.
On the night of March 3rd 2017 the robbers stole a golden coin, 57cm in diameter and 100kg heavy, worth approximately 3,8 Million Euro.
The perpetrators entered the building via the S-Bahn tracks between 3:20am and 3:45 am using a ladder and transported the heavy spoils with a wheelbarrow.
Big Maple Leaf
The coin was minted in Canada in 2007 and is called ‘The Big Maple Leaf’. It is 99,999 percent pure gold.
A representative of the police said that it is most likely the thieves will melt down the coin as it is way too famous to be resold thanks to worldwide media coverage.
look_out: Tickets for all five museums are available from the website above. Skip the queues by purchasing on-line.
If you plan to visit at least two museums, get the combined ticket for all the museums for 18 Euro, reduced 9 Euro. Free entry to Under 19s.
Bust of Nefertiti
Taking photos without flashlight and tripod is allowed. Only the bust of Nefertiti may not be photographed at all.

attractions.busStop: A Place worthy of its name

stopInfo.title: Lustgarden
teaser: It’s time for more selfies and a refreshing beer in one off the most historic gardens of Berlin! Welcome to the Lustgarten. Since the 16th century people have been regularly misbehaving in the hidden pavilions on the grounds.
history: The Lustgarten is part of the famous Berlin Museum Island [tour coming soon] and is located on what used to be a massive wetland. The area was originally part of the City Castle which today can be found on the other side of the street.
The Park was first mentioned in 1471 when it was used as a large herbal garden.
In 1646 the botanic chaos was brought some order by royal gardener Michael Hanf and master gardener Johann Sigismund Elßholtz. The duo constructed the Lustgarten following several Dutch prototypes.
In 1652 for the first time in Berlin tomatoes and potatoes (weird exotic plants from the New World at the time) were planted in the Lustgarten.
King Frederick William I of Prussia loved his army and didn’t much care for gardens. He leveled the area in 1713 and turned it into a parade ground with no plants whatsoever.
On February 7th 1933 more than 200.000 Germans protested against Reich Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his politics in the Lustgarten. Shortly after, public opposition to the party was banned.
In 1934, Lustgarten was converted to host mass rallies of up to 1 million people.
Olympic Games procession, 1936

Air raids by the Allied Forces destroyed most of the Museum Island but mostly spared the Lustgarten. A renovation of the Lustgarten from 1998 until 1999 cost Berlin a whopping 3,5 Million Euro and won the Price for German Landscape Architecture in 2001.
qi: Lustgarten

The Lustgarten was very true to its own name over the centuries. Kings and important heads of states are said to have indulged in extramarital fun with their mistresses or prostitutes in one of the many pavilions and hidden corners on the grounds.
look_out: Herbert Baum memorial

Freedom fighter Herbert Baum (February 10th 1912 – June 11th 1942) was one of the men responsible for the arson attack on the Lustgarten on March 18th 1942 protesting an exhibition there called “The Soviet Paradis”. Baum and his co-conspirators were denunciated, arrested immediately and shortly after sentenced to death. Since 1981 a memorial stone remembers the “Resistance Group Baum”. It was never determined whether Herbert Baum died from his injuries suffered during torture or whether he committed suicide.
Stadtschloss, between 1890 und 1900

The red granite bowl with its 22 foot diameter was created by mason Christian Gottlieb Cantian who used a single block of granite found in a boulder just outside Berlin. Since 1831 the bowl is a regular constituent of the Lustgarten even though its location has changed a lot over the years.

attractions.busStop: Buckle up! There is lots to explore.

stopInfo.title: Berlin Dom
teaser: Buckle up! There is lots to explore.
Why the Berlin Dom could be a disappointment for history geeks, who is haunting the place at night in the crypt and who took down the building a nudge? Read all about it here!
history: The Berlin Dom is the biggest church in Berlin.
Highlights are the baptistery, the Matrimonial Chapel, the Imperial Staircase, the Crypt of the Hohenzollern, The Dom Museum and of course the Sermon Church with its stately dome.

• Architect: Julius Raschdorff
  • Financed by: Frederick William II.
  • Style: Neo-Renaissance, Neo-Baroque
  • Built: 1894 until 1905
Before the Dom was built the area had a smaller court chapel belonging to the royal family of the Hohenzollern in the exact same place.
Before Wold War II the cupola of the Dom hat four corner towers and a height of 114 meters.

Towards the end of the war the Dom hit it pretty hard. First a bomb in the neighbouring Burgstraße destroyed all the windows detonating. The day after the attack massive cracks in the corner towers could be seen.
Finally on May 24th 1944 the cupola was hit by bombs.
A liquid incendiary bomb turned the Sermon Church and the Crypt of the Hohenzollern into ashes.
Reconstruction didn’t happen for no less than 30 years after World War II.
In 1983 the outer facade of the Dom was finally repaired.
Work on the interior found its end on June 29th 2002 by finishing the eighth dome mosaic.
Since having been rebuilt the dome of the Dome is only just 98 meter high, therefore it was taken down a nudge by Allied Forces.
qi: Most of Berlin’s residential houses were built around the turn of the century. Which is why the Dome (opened on February 27th 1905) is jokingly being referred to as a „Newbuilt” by long-established Berliners.
The Crypt of the Hohenzollern with its mouldy smell and the little coffins for children stimulates the fantasy of its visitors since year one.

The ghost of a little girl is said to haunt the place. Her ghost is allegedly looking for her mother, who is not buried in the crypt. The girl is supposed to be the illegitimate child of a high ranking family member of the Hohenzollern. Her sarcophagus had no name engraved and therefore „The Child Ghost” has to roam the crypt for all eternity.
look_out: The main altar of the Dom was created in 1850 by Friedrich August Stüler. It did find a new home in the Dom rebuilt. The altar is made of white marble und yellow(ish) onyx. The style is a mixture of a Lutheranian block altar and a reformed table altar. It symbolises the coalition of both churches into The Unified Church of Prussia.
The rim around the dome consists of 20 angel statues made of copper.
Dome Centre & Holy Ghost Dove
In the centre of the dome you can see an oculus showing a Holy Ghost Dove in a corona. Underneath it there are eight dome mosaics showing scenes from the Sermon on the Mount.
Queen Dorothea sarcophagus

Underneath the organ gallery in the crypt there are two luxurious sarcophaguses for the Great Elector Friedrich Wilhelm and his second wife Dorothea as well as a funerary monument for Frederick William III.
King Friedrich William I sarcophagus
The sarcophagus of King Friedrich William I. and his wife Sophie Charlotte can be found underneath the southern gallery.

Panoramic image of the Berlin CathedralThe interior of the church with organ, pulpit and altar
Sauer organThe Berliner Dom organ
Sauer organThe Berliner Dom Interior

attractions.busStop: A unique permanent exhibition of antique arts

stopInfo.title: Old Museum
teaser: 18 giant ionic columns, an ample hall with a perron that basically screams ‘Selfie!’ and a unique permanent exhibition of antique arts – The Old Museum has lots to offer.
Find a romantic reunification that won’t only interest historians. Who is the lady meeting one of her many former lovers?
history: Altes Museum, 1900
The magnificent building was opened to the public in 1830 after a seven year long construction period and has ever since become the centre of the Museum Island.

• Architect: Karl Friedrich Schinkel
  • Financed by: Frederick William III, King of Prussia
  • Style: Classicism
  • Built: 1823 until 1830
  • Height: 20m
  • Length: 87m
  • Width: 55m
  • Area: 4.785 Square Meters
The green area, formerly a shaggy swamp, was mentioned for the first time in 1471 and originally served as a huge herb garden after its development.
The Old Museum used to be called “The King’s Museum”.
View of Antique Collection
Since 1904 it is home to the wold renowned Antique Collection.

Light case bombs destroyed most of the structure in 1941 and 1943. On May 8th 1945 the whole building burnt down destroying most of the frescos made by Karl Friedrich Schinkel in the vestibule and the backside of the pillared hall.
Altes Museum, 1950
Repairing the damages of World War II took up until 1966.
Since 1998 the basement of the museum is home to a collection showing interesting aspect of Roman city culture, Greek mythology and the latest archaeological findings.
qi: Meet Cleopatra, the Egyptian queen who used to be the star of the Old Museum.
Marblebust of Cleopatra
She took the long route to Berlin. The bust of the former ruler today can be seen in the Roman Collection inside the museum.

Before that the sculpture all of a sudden turned up in a private collection of a Majorcan cardinal. He claimed to have found it at an excavation at the Appian Way (one of the earliest and strategically most important Roman roads).
Experts concluded that the bust must therefore have been made around the times when Cleopatra was visiting Caesar in Rome.
The Green Caesar
Many years later the former scandalous lovers have been reunited. The sculpture “The Green Caesar” is next to Cleopatra’s bust in the showroom of the Old Museum.
look_out: The inscription at the columns reads: FRIDERICVS GVILHELMVS III. STVDIO ANTIQVITATIS OMNIGENAE ET ARTIVM LIBERALIVM MVSEVM CONSTITVIT MDCCCXXVIII.
Translation: Frederick William III, King of Prussia donated this museum for the study of any kinds of antiquity and liberal arts in 1828.

By building the Old Museums the king pissed of a lot of his allies. Back in the days many born of royal blood were convinced that education and fine arts were privilege to the rich. A public exhibition of rare cultural artefacts cause a lot of disapproval.

attractions.stopName: The Sculpture Garden of the Colonnades Yard
attractions.busStop: Free and relaxing stroll around the statues

stopInfo.title: The Sculpture Garden of the Colonnades Yard
teaser: This relaxing but yet informative walk doesn’t cost you a penny.
You can do it at any time, don’t have to worry about annoying opening hours and will learn a lot about the sculptures and their fascinating background stories.
history: The grounds measure 12.900  square meters and is fenced in by boxwood hedges.
King Frederick William IV of Prussia explicitly asked for the colonnades, understanding the columns would be a linking element between the different museums.
The public green space was created in 1880 by Eduard Neide and since hasn’t changed much despite countless renovations on the ground.
Today’s details and ambiance were created by landscaper Levin Monsigny.
The Sculpture Garden was reopened on June 6th 2010.
The colonnade along the Spree is separated by three pavilions that resemble little temples.
qi: Of course we could all pretend we know but here are some facts for the more honest among us:
Colonnade in front of Alte Nationalgalerie
A colonnade is a long sequence of columns joined by their entablature, often free standing or as part of a building.
In contrast to the arcade it has straight timber-work.

Other impressive examples are the colonnades of St. Peter‘s Square in Rome, the Stoa in Athens and countles therapeuthic baths in the city of Baden-Baden, Lauterbach, Putbus, Karlsbad, Marienbad, Kyselka and Heiligendamm.
look_out: „Equestrian Statue of King Frederick William IV“

Alexander Calandrelli (1834–1903): „Equestrian Statue of King Frederick William IV of Prussia”, Bronze. The sculptures in the pedestal represent Religion, Art, History and Philosophy. Fun Fact: Artist Alexander Calandrelli also created the relievo on the base of the Victory Column/Siegessäule.
„Diana“

Reinhold Felderhoff (1865 - 1919): „Diana“, Bronze. The 1,74 meter tall statue shows the Roman godess hunting. The famous piece was first shown at the Große Berliner Kunstausstellung (Thje Great Berlin Art Exhibition) in 1898. Looking at the soft shaping of the hair you see the influence of the so called Begas School.
„Amazon on horseback“

Louis Tuaillon (1862–1919): „Amazon on horseback”, Bronze. The sculpture shows the Amazon as the embodiment of self-control, austerity and focus and not as an aggressive warrioress as commonly thought. The young woman rides on a horseback holding a battle axe in her right hand. Louis Tuaillon  created two more sculptures of the same name. One can be found in Tiergarten, the other in „Am Haus Doorn“ in the Netherlands.
„The Sower“

Constantin Meunier (1831–1905): „The Sower“, Bronze. The sculpture represents worth and the burden of hard work. The man is sowing seeds, he is not a seaman as the German name („Der Sämann“) suggests. The sculpture was produced three times. The two other two can be seen in Brussels and Frankfurt am Main.
„Lion“

August Gaul (1869 – 1921): „Lion“, Bronze. Gaul studied the animals he sculptured in zoos. It was important to him to capture their “essence and nature”. In 1890 he won a season ticket to the Berlin Zoological Garden. Animals became his primary sculpture subjects.
„Hercules and the Nemean Lion“

Max Klein (1847–1908): „Hercules and the Nemean Lion”, Bronze. The Greek hero strangles the unbeatable lion with his bare hands. To fully understand the composition of the sculpture you will have to walk around it to get a feel for the “compositional chaos.
„The Fisherman (Saved)“

Adolf Brütt (1855–1939): „The Fisherman (Saved)“, Bronze. The beardy fisherman holding a girl saved from drowning in his strong arms made the then 22 year old Adolf Brütt an overnight sensation on the art scene. Brütt was born in Husum on the North Sea and claimed to have witnessed the dramatic scenes himself as a young boy.
„Female Archer“

Ferdinand Lepcke (1866 – 1909): „Female Archer“, Bronze. The origin of the name of the sculpture isn’t quite clear. Elsewhere, it is referred to as “Amazon” or “Diana”. The artist preferred nude sculptures of young women. His ideal of beauty is clearly shaped by the beau ideal of his time. After his death Ferdinand’s brother sold a lot of his art, including the license to duplicate which ultimately made his works known to a broader clientèle.
„Centaur and Nymph“

Reinhold Begas (1831 – 1911): „Centaur and Nymph“, Bronze. The young woman tries to elegantly get on the centaur’s broad back. Assisting her, the mythological creature lowers his legs and hold out his left hand to supports her. Experts interpret this sculpture in two ways. It  embodies the  the contrast between the sexes and their roles as well as the contrast between antiquity and modernity.
„The Monument“

Atelier Van Lieshout: „The Monument“, Bronze. This sculpture will only be seen until September 2017. It symbolises the social and political past of the German Empire in the years before World War I and also stands as a warning to the present and the future.
„Hun on Horseback“

Erich Hösel (1869 – 1953): „Hun on Horseback“, Bronze. It is one of the most extraordinary equestrian statues of the late 19th century. The horse of the hun gets frightened by a scull laying on the floor while the warrior bends down to inspect the bones with a smile. Erich Hösel was named Head of design at the famous Dresden China Manufactory and made his famous sculpture out of porcelain, .

attractions.busStop: The New Museum has a lot to offer even if you decided to stay outside

stopInfo.title: New Museum
teaser: A fashionable headgear that could be used as a calendar, a cat fight of monumental proportion and a “Swedish” misuse after the WW2 bombing – The New Museum has a lot to offer even if you decided to stay outside.
To whoever pays the entrance: We will provide you with cool and extraordinary additional information. You rather save the entrance money?
On this tour we will give you a colourful info-mix that will make you sound like a proper B-Towner.
history: Neues Museum, 1862
The New Museum was built between 1843 and 1855. It is understood to be the masterstroke of architect Friedrich August Stüler.

Stüler used clever iron constructions, light bricks and vaults made of tiles. Back in the days that kind of construction was revolutionary and was only made possible due to the advances of the upcoming industrialisation.
The Park was first mentioned in 1471 as it was uses as a massive herbal garden.
The inside of the building is traversed by an iron skeleton and a magnificent system of pillars, cornerstones and beams. Even today some of those structures can be seen through the plastering.
More than 9.000 exhibition pieces are shown on four floors (one of them being in the cellar).

• Architect: Friedrich August Stüler
  • Financed by: King Frederick William IV of Prussia
  • Style: late Classicism
  • Built: 1843 until 1855
  • Height: 31m
  • Length: 105m
  • Width: 40m
  • Area: 8.000 Square Meters
The New Museum shows the fascinating development of the prehistoric Eurasian cultures from the Old Stone Age until the High Middle Ages.
The oldest exhibition piece, a biface from the Old Stone Age, dates back 700.000 years. The youngest addition to the exhibition is a peace of barbwire from the Berlin Wall.
Neues Museum Egyptian courtyard
The New Museum is also home to the Egyptian Museum and the Papyrus Collection since 2009.
Berliner Goldhut

Highlights of the exhibition are: The Berlin Gold Hat („Berliner Goldhut“) is an artifact dating back to the Bronze Age. The mysterious symbolic is understood to be some kind of calendar helping to predict the units of the sun and the moon.
Neanderthal skull, Le Moustier

The Neanderthal skull, Le Moustier, was found during an archaeological excavation in France on March 7th 1908. It is believed to be 45.000 years old and was reconstructed masterfully thanks to modern computer technology.
Bust of Nefertiti

In 1920 James Simon donated the most famous exhibition piece and a proper visitor magnet: The bust of Nefertiti. She was sculptured during times of the 18th dynasty (New Empire) between 1353 and 1336 BC. Trying to determine the value of Nefertiti different opinions arose. The bust is officially insured for 300 million Euro. Though a lot of experts seem to think that the Egyptian lady is worth more than 400 million Euro.
In 1939 the New Museum closed its doors to protect the valuable artifacts from the budding war.
Original staircase, 1850

That was a good call considering that shortly after that the first air raids on the Museum Island started. On November 23rd 1943 the central staircase and the fresco on the wall depicting the History of Mankind were burnt down completely.
Heavy bombings in February 1945 destroyed the crossover to the Ols Museum and the whole Northwest Wing of the museum completely.
Neues Museum, Ruine, Ägyptische Statue, 1949

After the war the New Museum was nearly forgotten and carved out a miserable existence as a ruin. It was only in 1989 that the first stones for an original reconstruction were laid. Unfortunately the project came to a hold after the reunification of Germany.

Between 1999 and 2009 the New Museum was finally restored to its former glory following the so called master plan for the Museum Island. The reconstruction followed plans from architect David Chipperfield and did cost about 295 million Euro.
qi: The Museum Island nearly saw a cat fight of truly monumental proportions.  In the Old Museum the portrait of Cleopatra and the famous bust of Nefertiti competed over the affection of the visitors. Since October 2009 the problem was resolved by moving Nefertiti to the New Museum. Now both ladies don’t have to share the title of “Queen of the Crowd” anymore.
Building the New Museum gave Berlin an architectural premiere. For the first time ever a steam engine was used in construction.
After World War II the building more and more resembled a lumber room. Countless rooms were used as storage for old furniture making the New Museum some kind of early IKEA.
look_out: The inscription of the median risalit explains the history of the New Museum in gilded copper letters.
It reads: MUSEUM A PATRE BEATISSIMO CONDITUM AMPLIAVIT FILIUS MDCCCLV
Translation: The son extended the Museum build by his most holy father in 1855.
Father and son of course refer to King Frederick William IV of Prussia and his dad Frederick William III.

The gable is mounted by a Borussia made by artist Gustav Blaeser. The statue stands for a female allegorical figure as a personification of Prussia and shows that the building used to be part of the complex of Prussian Museums.
Zinc relief by August Kiß
On the West Wing of the gable you can see a zinc relief by artist August Kiß. It reads: The art instructs industry and applied arts.

attractions.busStop: Impressive art from the French Revolution up until World War I.

stopInfo.title: Old National Gallery
teaser: When deciding what kind of art was to be exhibited in the National Gallery the responsible parties were of very different opinions, to put it mildly.
Find out who, after many years, turned out to be right all along!
history: The Old National Gallery shows rather impressive art from the French Revolution up until World War I.

• Architect: Friedrich August Stüler and after his death his successor Johann Heinrich Strack
  • Financed by: Frederick William IV.
  • Style: Late Classicism and early Neo-Renaissance
  • Built: 1867 until 1876
Before construction could even start old buildings like the Orangerie and the Welpersche Bathhouse had to be torn down.
In 1867 the laying of the first stone was administrated by Johann Heinrich Strack.
The Old National Gallery was opened on March 22nd 1876 in presence of the Emperor.
Because of the latest iron constructions and brick-built ceilings the building was understood to be fireproof.
Heinrich's collection - Schinkel's Gothic Church on a rock by the sea

In the beginning the art collection was quite pathetic and only consisted of 262 paintings. They were a donation by the late banker Joachim Heinrich and made the humble beginnings of the Old National Gallery possible in the first place.
In 1896 Hugo von Tschudi took over the administration of the museum. He caused a scandal by starting to collect impressionistic art with Manet, Monet and Degas being the main focus

His successor Ludwig Justi even took it a step further and incorporated expressionistic exhibits in the collection. We know today that this was a very good call. Back in the days the choice wasn’t a popular one as the Old National Gallery was originally meant exclusively for contemporary Prussian art. For that exact reason the exhibit was divided into two sections: The National Gallery I and the National Gallery II.

After Hitler came into power the taste in art changed especially in regard of foreign artist. The new administrator Ludwig Justi didn’t have much time to change the concept of the gallery as it was closed down in September 1939.

Especially toward the end of the war the Old National Gallery had to withstand heavy bombings and was damaged quite badly. The allegedly fireproof building went down in flames eventually after heavy artillery.
Until today it is not quite clear which artifacts were destroyed by the fire or simply looted by the Russian soldiers.

Despite the devastating destruction the Old National Gallery came back on its feet rather quickly. In 1949 and after intensive reconstruction what was left of the exhibit was shown to the public again.
After the Berlin Wall came up the art was divided into East and West.
Even after the German Reunification the Old National Gallery didn’t return to its former glory before December 2nd 2001.

Fancy a little tour? On the first floor of the Old National Gallery you can find selected works of the French Realism (Jean Désiré Gustave Courbet, Charles-François Daubigny and others). The epos  „Heldengschichten” and paintings like „Das Balkonzimmer” and  „Das Eisenwalzwerk” by Berlin artist Adolf Menzel are the highlighs of this floor.

On the second storey of the building you can find artists like Anselm Feuerbach, Hans von Marées, Edouard Manet, Auguste Renoir, Claude Monet, Paul Cézanne, Edgar Degas, Auguste Rodin and early works of Max Liebermann.

The third floor is dedicated to the times of Goethe. Most recognisable names here are Jakob Philipp Hackerts, Anton Graff, Peter Cornelius, Wilhelm Schadow, Friedrich Overbeck und Philipp Veit. The German Romantic is represented by artists like Caspar David Friedrich and Karl Friedrich Schinkel. Important artist from the Biedermeier period are Carl Spitzweg, Johann Erdmann Hummel, Ferdinand Georg Waldmüller and of course Eduard Gaertner with his beautiful impressions of the city of Berlin.
qi: The construction of the Old National Gallery was only just made possible by the generous donation by the very wealthy financier Joachim Heinrich Wilhelm Wagener who left his own extensive art collection to the King of Prussia after his death in 1861. Before that there wasn’t even any art worth showing.

The special exhibition “Impressionism/ Expressionism: Changing Art” was the most sought after event of the Old National Gallery counting as many as 245.694 visitors. This fact was seen with a mischievous smile by art critics considering the scandal those modern paintings caused back in their days.
look_out: The building very cleverly unites three different architectural elements: The facade of the gable and the columns very much resemble those of a temple. The gigantic staircase looks like it was taken from a castle and the attached apse looks like stolen from the blueprint of a church.

On the perron towers an equestrian statue of Frederick William IV. It is made of bronze and surrounded by a couple of different statues on the socket: “Religion”, “Art (Poetry)”, “History” and “Philosophy”. The sculptures were made in 1886 by artist Alexander Calandrelli.
Translation: The son extended the Museum build by his most holy father in 1855.
Father and son of course refer to King Frederick William IV of Prussia and his dad Frederick William III.

The gable is mounted by a Borussia made by artist Gustav Blaeser. The statue stands for a female allegorical figure as a personification of Prussia and shows that the buiding used to be part of the complex of Prussian Museums.
On the West Wing of the gable you can see a zinc relief by artist August Kiß. It reads: The art instructs industry and applied arts.

attractions.busStop: Strictly speaking what you see is not what you get.

stopInfo.title: Pergamonmuseum
teaser: Strictly speaking what you see is not what you get.
Want to know the clever trick the museum operators used to protect the art from being destroyed during World War II bombings?
history: The museum you see today in front of you strictly speaking isn’t the original. The first Pergamonmuseum was built from 1897 until 1899 by architect Fritz Wolff and opened to the public on December 18th 1901 by William II, German Emperor and King of Prussia.
Pergamonmuseum I
In 1908 the building was torn down and had to make room for the Pergamonmuseum II.

Last but not least! The second Pergamonmuseum was built between 1910 and 1930 as the last of five museum buildings on the Museum Island following the design of Alfred Messel. After his death his pupil Ludwig Hoffmann took over the coordination of construction.
The building has three different wings accommodating three different museums: The Antique Collection, The Near Eastern Museum and the Museum for Islamic Art.
Altar to Zeus in the Pergamonmuseum
Because of ongoing construction work at the Altar of Pergamum the main attraction of the museum can’t be seen by the public until the year 2023.
Other Highlights of the Pergamonmuseum are the reconstruction of the Market Door of Milet, The Door of Ischtar including the procession street of Babylon and the Mschatta Facade.
Air strikes during World War II hit the building hard. Luckily most of the art could be brought to a safe place before the first bombs hit.
In 1954 the Antique Collection could be opened to the public again after some provisional reconstruction.
In the year of 2007 the Pergamonmuseum was the most visited museum in all of Berlin counting 1.135.000 visitors.
qi: Exhibits that were too big to be transported during World War II fighting were simply walled in to protect them from bomb and fire damages.
After the war ended a massive chunk of the exhibition was taken to Moscow and Leningrad (todays Saint Petersburg) by the Red Army and brought to so called Victory Museums in Russia.
In 1958 however the former Soviet Union gave back most of the art work to what had by then become the GDR.
look_out: The entrance to the Pergamonmuseum during times of construction isn’t at its normal place at the address Kupfergraben anymore but can be found at the Kolonnadenhof, between the Old National Gallery and the New Museum.
The exterior facade is made from shell limestone, granodiorite from a region called the Lausitz, granite porphyrite and chalk stone from Croatia. It is made to show off.

Berlin is poor, but sexy! For this reason not all four exterior facade could be made out of the expensive materials. Therefore the north facade (Facing the Bode Museum), the eastern walls (facing Hackischer Mrakt) and the south façade are kept rather simple knowing full well that they won’t be seen by a lot of people.

attractions.busStop: Fancy a free concert in the summer?

stopInfo.title: Bode Museum
teaser: Fancy a free concert in the summer?
Read all the gripping details to one of Berlin’s most spectacular art burglaries and get some interesting facts about the architecture of the building while you are here:
history: The Bode Museum opened its doors under its old name Kaiser-Friedrich-Museum on October 18th 1904 after a seven year long building period.
Byzantinische Art
Highlights of the show are the Collection of Sculptures, the Museum for Byzantine Art, the 150 picture strong Painting-Gallery and the Coin Cabinet.
-b2-Architect: Ernst Eberhard von Ihne -b2-Construction Manager: Max Hasak -b2-Style: Neo-Baroque -b2-Built: 1897 until 1904
Before construction could begin two old building had to be torn down. The Old Berlin Flour House and the so called Art Barrack had to make room for the new build.
The triangular plot on the northwest tip of the Museum Island is more than 6.000 Square Meters big.
Architect Ernst Eberhard von Ihne made the impossible possible and gave the museum the appearance of being completely symmetric.
Different transepts create five patios.
Equestrian statue, main hall
1. The big dome hall with its impressive staircase and a copy of the equestrian statue of the Great Elector made by artist Andreas Schlüter.
2. The Kamecke-Hall with statues by Andreas Schlüter.
3. The Italian renaissance styled Basilica.
4. The religious paintings and a resurrection altar from Florence can be found in the chapels on both sides.
5. The small rococo styled dome hall with the breath taking staircase and the statues of Venus and Mars on its socket. They were created by artist Jean-Baptiste Pigalle.
During World War II the Bode Museum got off relatively easy. Bombs only destroyed the roof of the building. It was replaced in 1951.
In 1956 the museum was renamed after administrator Wilhelm von Bode.
Over the years more reconstruction became necessary. On October 17th 2006 the Bode Museum was reopened after a six year long remodeling period.
qi: In March 2017 one of the most spectacular art robberies of Berlin took place at the Bode-Museum.
On the night of March 3rd 2017 the robbers stole a golden coin, 57cm in diameter and 100 kilogram heavy, worth approximately 3,8 Million Euro.
The perpetrators entered the building via the S-Bahn tracks between 3:20am and 3:45 am using a ladder and transported the heavy spoils with a wheelbarrow.
Regardless of the many tips from the public the case has not been solved yet.
Big Maple Leaf
The coin was minted in Canada in 2007 and is called ‘The Big Maple Leaf’. It is 99,999 percent pure gold.
A representative of the police said that it is most likely the thieves will melt down the coin as it is way too famous to be resold thanks to worldwide media coverage.
look_out: One year ago no less than 59 statues originally belonging to the Bode Museum were rediscovered in the Pushkin Museum in Moscow. Until that day it was believed they had been lost in the war.
At the entrance of the Bode Museum during every Sunday in the summer months visitors can experience a free Classic Open Air Concert.
